didactic: $\mathrm{N_2O}$ diffuses into air-filled spaces ~34 times faster than $\mathrm{N_2}$ leaves, so it expands or pressurizes closed or semi-closed cavities (e.g., middle ear, pneumothorax, intracranial air, obstructed bowel, pneumoperitoneum, and intraocular gas). Consequently, avoid $\mathrm{N_2O}$ in closed-space surgeries (tympanoplasty, bowel obstruction, recent intravitreal SF6/C3F8) and when PONV risk is high. $\mathrm{N_2O}$ also increases PONV in a dose- and duration-dependent manner (mitigated by TIVA with propofol and multimodal prophylaxis). When these concerns are absent, selective use of 50% $\mathrm{N_2O}$ can reduce volatile requirements by about 0.5 MAC, maintain hemodynamic stability, and facilitate rapid wake-up. Practical rules: avoid $\mathrm{N_2O}$ for middle ear surgery and retinal gas (for at least 7–10 days for SF6, longer for C3F8), known or suspected pneumothorax, intracranial air, and distended bowel. Use it cautiously in laparoscopy and in patients with significant PONV risk factors (female, nonsmoker, history of PONV/motion sickness, opioids). Balancing benefits (MAC reduction, analgesia) against these risks guides selective, case-by-case use.
educationalObjective: Avoid nitrous oxide in closed-space surgery or high PONV risk and use it selectively for MAC reduction.

questionText: A 34-year-old woman (BMI 24) presents for suspension microlaryngoscopy with laser excision of bilateral vocal fold papillomas. The ENT surgeon plans shared-airway surgery using intermittent apnea and high-frequency jet ventilation through the rigid laryngoscope, requests FiO2 ≤ 0.30, and does not want a cuffed endotracheal tube in place. She has severe prior postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), mild exercise-induced asthma, and a family history of malignant hyperthermia (uncle affected); she has not been tested and will be treated as susceptible. Standard anesthesia machine is available, but the jet ventilator has no vaporizer, and end-tidal agent monitoring will not be possible during the open-airway portions. A processed EEG depth monitor is available. Which maintenance anesthetic plan is MOST appropriate for this case?

answers.text: Propofol–remifentanil total intravenous anesthesia with neuromuscular blockade and processed EEG depth monitoring
answers.explanation: Best integrates all constraints: avoids volatile agents in an MH-susceptible patient, is deliverable and titratable during open-airway/jet ventilation when end-tidal agent monitoring is impossible, supports low FiO2 for laser fire safety, provides reliable immobility with NMB, and reduces PONV versus inhaled agents. Processed EEG mitigates awareness risk during TIVA when no end-tidal anesthetic is measurable.

answers.text: Sevoflurane maintenance via insufflation through the laryngoscope with spontaneous ventilation to leverage bronchodilation
answers.explanation: Insufflated volatile during an open-airway case provides unpredictable alveolar concentrations, no end-tidal monitoring, and significant OR pollution; it also exposes an MH-susceptible patient to a trigger and increases PONV. Bronchodilation benefits do not override delivery and safety constraints.

answers.text: Desflurane with 50% N2O via a cuffed laser endotracheal tube for precise end-tidal control and rapid emergence
answers.explanation: A laser ETT would obstruct the surgeon’s view in suspension microlaryngoscopy with jet ventilation and conflicts with the planned open-airway technique. Volatiles trigger MH, desflurane can irritate the airway, and N2O increases PONV and supports airway fire in laser cases.

answers.text: Sevoflurane at ~0.7 MAC supplemented with dexmedetomidine infusion to limit PONV during jet ventilation
answers.explanation: Volatile delivery remains unreliable without a closed circuit or end-tidal monitoring during jet ventilation, and any MAC of a triggering agent is contraindicated in MH susceptibility. Dexmedetomidine may reduce PONV and opioid needs but does not solve the fundamental delivery and MH-trigger issues.

answers.text: Ketamine infusion (about 2 mg/kg/h) as the sole maintenance anesthetic to avoid volatile agents
answers.explanation: While ketamine avoids MH triggers, as a sole anesthetic it is poorly titratable for surgical immobility, increases secretions, and risks dysphoria; it does not reduce PONV as effectively as propofol. A propofol–remifentanil TIVA provides superior hypnotic control and rapid, precise titration for shared-airway surgery.

didactic: In shared/open-airway surgery (rigid laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, jet ventilation), volatile anesthetics cannot be reliably delivered or monitored; choose TIVA when you cannot measure end-tidal agent concentration. MH susceptibility absolutely contraindicates volatile agents and succinylcholine; propofol–remifentanil TIVA is the standard alternative. Laser airway cases require minimizing oxidizers (avoid N2O and keep FiO2 ≤ 0.30) to reduce fire risk. Propofol-based TIVA reduces PONV by roughly 30–50% compared with volatile maintenance, aligning with this patient’s high PONV risk. Use processed EEG (e.g., BIS/PSI target ~40–60) during TIVA—especially with neuromuscular blockade—to mitigate awareness risk when no end-tidal anesthetic is available. Although volatiles have bronchodilatory effects helpful in asthma, delivery feasibility, MH risk, and surgical airway requirements take precedence in selecting maintenance anesthesia.
educationalObjective: Choose inhaled anesthesia versus TIVA by balancing airway surgery needs, PONV risk, comorbidities, and monitoring requirements.

questionText:
A 29-year-old woman with moderate persistent asthma (albuterol inhaler several times per week, on inhaled budesonide) presents for laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy. She received albuterol preoperatively and has no wheeze on exam. After IV induction with fentanyl, lidocaine, propofol, and rocuronium, a 7.0-mm cuffed ETT is placed. Maintenance is begun with sevoflurane at ~0.6 MAC in air/O2 (FiO2 0.5), FGF 2 L/min, VT 6–7 mL/kg IBW, PEEP 5 cm H2O. Ten minutes after pneumoperitoneum, peak inspiratory pressure rises to 35 cm H2O with expiratory wheeze; ETCO2 is 45 mm Hg and SpO2 98%. Plateau pressure has risen only slightly compared to peak, consistent with increased airway resistance. You rule out tube obstruction/kink and administer albuterol MDI via the circuit, with partial improvement.

Which maintenance plan will most effectively reduce airway resistance and minimize further bronchospasm?

answers.text: Increase sevoflurane to 1.2–1.5 MAC in O2/air (avoid N2O) and continue intermittent albuterol as needed
answers.explanation: Volatile agents (especially sevoflurane) produce dose-dependent bronchodilation and blunt reflex-mediated bronchoconstriction; deepening volatile anesthesia is the most immediate and reliable strategy during intraoperative bronchospasm.

answers.text: Switch to desflurane at ~1.0 MAC to facilitate a faster emergence
answers.explanation: Desflurane is pungent and can increase airway resistance and trigger bronchospasm, particularly in patients with reactive airways and with rapid concentration changes.

answers.text: Add 50% N2O to reduce the sevoflurane requirement and improve bronchodilation
answers.explanation: N2O has no bronchodilatory effect; reducing sevoflurane to make room for N2O would likely lessen, not enhance, bronchodilation.

answers.text: Convert to TIVA with propofol–remifentanil and add a low-dose ketamine infusion
answers.explanation: TIVA with propofol and ketamine is an acceptable alternative if volatiles are contraindicated, but inhaled anesthetics provide more rapid and predictable bronchodilation; ketamine may increase secretions and often requires an antisialagogue.

answers.text: Maintain with isoflurane 0.5 MAC and use morphine boluses for analgesia
answers.explanation: Light anesthesia favors reflex bronchoconstriction, and morphine can release histamine and worsen bronchospasm; deeper volatile anesthesia (sevo/isoflurane) is preferred.

didactic: Volatile anesthetics (sevoflurane and isoflurane) directly relax airway smooth muscle via reduced intracellular Ca2+ availability and inhibition of vagal reflex pathways, producing dose-dependent bronchodilation at clinical MACs. Desflurane is relatively airway-irritating and may increase airway resistance—avoid it in reactive airways, especially with rapid up-titration. TIVA with propofol (attenuates airway reflexes) and ketamine (bronchodilator) is a valid alternative when volatiles are undesirable (e.g., MH susceptibility), but in active or threatened bronchospasm, deepening a non-pungent volatile often yields the most immediate improvement. Avoid histamine-releasing drugs (e.g., morphine, atracurium) and ensure adequate depth; adjuncts include inhaled β2-agonists, IV lidocaine, and steroids. Ventilation should accommodate longer expiratory times because airway resistance is elevated: $R_{aw} = (P_{peak} - P_{plat})/\text{flow}$ and the time constant is $\tau = R \times C$, so high $R$ mandates a lower respiratory rate and prolonged expiration to prevent air-trapping. Practical rule: in asthmatics with rising $P_{peak}$ and wheeze, first deepen sevoflurane to >1 MAC, deliver albuterol, and avoid desflurane and N2O until the airway stabilizes.
educationalObjective: Choose maintenance strategies for reactive airways, leveraging volatile bronchodilation versus TIVA with adjuncts.

questionText:
A 72-kg man with suspected malignant hyperthermia undergoes a 5-hour thoracolumbar decompression with MEP/SEP monitoring. He will be induced supine, then turned prone with both arms tucked. You have a reliable 18G forearm IV and a 20G foot IV; once prone, IV sites will be largely out of view. The hospital recently experienced brief power “flickers,” and your biomedical team notes the anesthesia machine’s auxiliary outlets are not on an uninterruptible power supply. You plan TIVA with propofol and remifentanil and processed EEG monitoring. 

Which of the following is the most appropriate TIVA setup and plan to minimize the risk of awareness from infusion interruption in this case?

answers.text: Use separate syringe pumps for propofol (TCI to $C_{eff}$ 3–4 μg/mL) and remifentanil (2–4 ng/mL) connected to a short, low–dead-space manifold secured at the distal IV hub with a separate carrier at 50–75 mL/h; keep the infusion tubing visible after positioning, plug pumps into red (emergency) outlets and confirm ≥2 h internal battery life, use processed EEG, taper remifentanil at dressing and reduce propofol 10–15 min before emergence.
answers.explanation: Distal connection minimizes dead space and flush boluses, a separate low carrier maintains patency without dilutional spikes, and verified emergency power plus internal battery mitigates power loss; processed EEG and a staged taper reduce awareness risk while enabling timely emergence.

answers.text: Y-site both infusions into a single long extension near the pumps with a 250 mL/h carrier to ensure delivery; plug pumps into the anesthesia machine auxiliary outlet; stop both infusions at skin closure and flush the line to speed wake-up.
answers.explanation: A long upstream Y-set increases dead space and risks a large propofol bolus with any flush; machine auxiliary outlets may drop during power transfer; abrupt cessation of both infusions increases awareness and hemodynamic volatility.

answers.text: Gravity-feed propofol through a 200 mm Hg pressure bag and drip chamber to avoid pump failure; run remifentanil by pump; rely on BIS to detect interruptions and keep the carrier off to avoid hypotension.
answers.explanation: Gravity TIVA is unsafe and unreliable; BIS changes lag delivery failure, and no carrier increases the risk of line occlusion and unrecognized infiltration.

answers.text: Place both infusions on an upstream manifold under the drapes at mid-chest with anti-siphon valves and no separate carrier; rely on cuff BP changes to detect infiltration; plug pumps into standard (white) outlets because internal batteries suffice for brief flickers.
answers.explanation: An upstream manifold under the drapes hides the line and increases dead space (delayed onset, flush bolus risk); white outlets may lose power; physiologic changes detect failure late.

answers.text: Position the propofol TCI infusion port 150 cm from the patient to promote mixing and smoother delivery; plug pumps into a power strip mounted on the bed so they remain powered during bed rotation; add 0.5 MAC volatile as backup.
answers.explanation: Long tubing increases dead space and bolus risk; bed-mounted power strips are not a reliable emergency power source; volatile “backup” is contraindicated in MH-susceptible patients.

didactic: Safe TIVA requires a reliable infusion source, secure and visible IV access, minimized dead space, and assured power. Use syringe pumps (not gravity) on red/emergency outlets and verify internal battery run time (often ≈2–4 h); anesthesia machine auxiliary outlets may not be backed up when the machine is on battery. Connect TIVA via a short, low–dead-space manifold at the distal IV hub with a separate carrier (e.g., 50–75 mL/h) to maintain patency while avoiding large dilutional swings; avoid long upstream Y-sites that create 0.5–2 mL of dead space, which can deliver a dangerous bolus when flushed (e.g., 5 mL residual at 10 mg/mL propofol = 50 mg ≈ 0.7 mg/kg in a 70-kg patient). Use processed EEG to reduce awareness risk and set pump occlusion/low-rate alarms; keep the infusion and IV site visible after positioning and physically secure tubing to prevent traction or disconnection. Induction: bolus and immediately start TCI or weight-based infusions (typical targets: propofol $C_{eff}$ 3–5 μg/mL, remifentanil 2–6 ng/mL), titrating to stimulus and neuromonitoring needs. Emergence: stop remifentanil at dressing (context-sensitive half-time ≈3–5 min) and reduce propofol to $C_{eff}$ 1–2 μg/mL 10–15 min before wake-up; avoid large line flushes. Practical rules: dedicate a lumen to TIVA, minimize dead space, maintain a modest carrier, verify emergency power and batteries, and never rely on gravity for general anesthesia.
educationalObjective: Construct a safe TIVA plan (induction, maintenance, emergence) including infusion pumps, IV access security, and backup power.

questionText: A 45-year-old woman (BMI 28) with a strong history of PONV and mild OSA on CPAP is scheduled for elective laparoscopic sigmoid colectomy on an ERAS colorectal pathway. She is opioid-naïve. Induction is uneventful; BP 118/72 mm Hg, HR 72, SpO2 100% on $F_{i}O_{2}$ 0.5. The surgeon anticipates a 2-hour case and requests minimal bowel distension to maintain pneumoperitoneum. You have access to regional anesthesia and standard adjuncts. Which intraoperative maintenance strategy best supports ERAS goals of opioid-sparing analgesia and early recovery for this patient?

answers.text: Propofol TIVA (e.g., 75–125 $\mu$g·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹) with IV lidocaine $1.5$ mg·kg⁻¹ bolus then $1.5$ mg·kg⁻¹·hr⁻¹, low-dose ketamine $0.2$ mg·kg⁻¹ bolus then $0.1$–$0.3$ mg·kg⁻¹·hr⁻¹, bilateral TAP blocks, scheduled acetaminophen/NSAID, dual PONV prophylaxis; avoid long-acting opioids.
answers.explanation: Propofol TIVA lowers PONV and facilitates rapid recovery; IV lidocaine reduces pain and postoperative ileus in colorectal surgery, and low-dose ketamine plus TAP blocks provide opioid-sparing analgesia without respiratory depression—well aligned with ERAS goals.

answers.text: Sevoflurane $\approx 1$ MAC with 50% N2O; intermittent hydromorphone (1–2 mg) and a single antiemetic; no regional anesthesia.
answers.explanation: N2O increases PONV and bowel distension, and hydromorphone promotes ileus and sedation; single-agent antiemesis is inadequate for a high-risk patient—contrary to ERAS priorities.

answers.text: Desflurane $\approx 1$ MAC with remifentanil infusion (0.2 $\mu$g·kg⁻¹·min⁻¹) throughout; stop remifentanil at closure; no multimodal adjuncts or blocks.
answers.explanation: Although emergence may be rapid, volatile anesthetics increase PONV and remifentanil without multimodal coverage risks opioid-induced hyperalgesia and high postoperative opioid needs—misaligned with opioid-sparing ERAS care.

answers.text: Sevoflurane $0.8$–$1.0$ MAC with bilateral TAP blocks, ketorolac, and acetaminophen, plus a morphine infusion (0.05 mg·kg⁻¹·hr⁻¹) to maintain comfort.
answers.explanation: Regional and non-opioids help, but a continuous morphine infusion undermines opioid-sparing goals and increases risks of ileus and respiratory depression, especially in OSA.

answers.text: Propofol TIVA with high-dose fentanyl (5 $\mu$g·kg⁻¹ at incision and 3 $\mu$g·kg⁻¹ hourly); no regional anesthesia; standard single-agent antiemetic.
answers.explanation: While TIVA reduces PONV, large-dose fentanyl opposes ERAS by increasing postoperative opioid needs, sedation, and PONV risk; lack of regional/multimodal support further impairs recovery.

didactic: ERAS maintenance prioritizes opioid-sparing, low-PONV techniques that enable early extubation, mobilization, and feeding. Propofol TIVA reduces PONV compared with volatile agents and avoids N2O, which increases PONV and bowel distension—key in laparoscopic and colorectal surgery. Multimodal analgesia should pair regional techniques (e.g., TAP blocks) with non-opioids such as acetaminophen and NSAIDs, and adjuncts like low-dose ketamine ($0.1$–$0.3$ mg·kg⁻¹·hr⁻¹) or dexmedetomidine ($0.2$–$0.7$ $\mu$g·kg⁻¹·hr⁻¹) to limit opioids without respiratory depression. An IV lidocaine regimen (bolus $1$–$1.5$ mg·kg⁻¹ then $1$–$2$ mg·kg⁻¹·hr⁻¹) can reduce pain and postoperative ileus in colorectal ERAS protocols. Avoid long-acting opioids and consider remifentanil only with robust multimodal coverage to mitigate opioid-induced hyperalgesia. Provide multimodal PONV prophylaxis in high-risk patients (e.g., dexamethasone + 5-HT3 antagonist), and use short-acting agents to support fast-track recovery.
educationalObjective: Coordinate maintenance choices with ERAS goals, emphasizing opioid-sparing and early recovery.

questionText: A 62-year-old, 82-kg man undergoes a 4-hour laparoscopic colectomy maintained with TIVA: propofol at 100 mcg/kg/min and remifentanil at 0.08 mcg/kg/min. He has normal hepatic and renal function. Twenty minutes remain until dressing; BIS is 45, hemodynamics are stable, and you plan to extubate at the end of dressing with good analgesia. Considering the context-sensitive half-times of propofol and remifentanil, which emergence plan best targets a timely, smooth extubation with adequate pain control?

answers.text: Turn off propofol now, administer hydromorphone 0.6 mg IV now, continue remifentanil through dressing, and stop remifentanil at the start of dressing.
answers.explanation: Propofol’s context-sensitive half-time (CSHT) increases with infusion duration (≈20–30 min after several hours), so turning it off ~20 min before the end allows hypnosis to wane on time. Remifentanil’s duration-independent CSHT (~3–5 min) lets you maintain analgesia until the last noxious stimulus; giving a longer-acting opioid now bridges analgesia when remifentanil is stopped.

answers.text: Turn off remifentanil now, continue propofol at the current rate until skin closure, and give analgesia in PACU.
answers.explanation: Stopping remifentanil first removes analgesia while painful stimulation persists, risking tachycardia and hypertension despite ongoing hypnosis. Delaying analgesia to PACU ignores remifentanil’s very short CSHT and invites emergence pain.

answers.text: Continue both infusions until the end of dressing, then stop them simultaneously to avoid intraoperative awareness.
answers.explanation: Simultaneous discontinuation at the end ignores propofol’s longer CSHT after prolonged infusion and will likely delay awakening and extubation. Awareness risk is low with current dosing and BIS 45; the issue is staggered offset, not simultaneous termination.

answers.text: Reduce both infusions by 50% every 5 minutes over the next 20 minutes and avoid additional opioids to prevent respiratory depression.
answers.explanation: A gradual taper does not overcome propofol’s duration-influenced CSHT and remifentanil will still dissipate within minutes, leaving inadequate analgesia. Avoiding longer-acting opioids disregards the need to bridge remifentanil’s rapid offset.

didactic: Context-sensitive half-time (CSHT) is the time for plasma concentration to fall by 50% after stopping an infusion and depends on infusion duration due to redistribution into peripheral compartments. Propofol’s CSHT increases with context—roughly ~10–15 min after 1 hour and ~20–30+ min after several hours (often <40 min even after very long cases)—so it should be turned off before the final noxious stimulus to allow timely recovery. Remifentanil’s CSHT is ~3–5 min and largely independent of infusion duration due to rapid esterase metabolism; its effect-site equilibrates quickly ($t_{1/2,ke0}\approx1$–2 min), so analgesia dissipates within minutes of stopping. Practical approach for long TIVA cases: stop propofol 10–20 min before the end, continue remifentanil to cover closure/dressing, and administer a longer-acting analgesic (e.g., hydromorphone 0.5–1 mg IV or fentanyl 1–2 mcg/kg) 10–20 min before stopping remifentanil. If remifentanil is stopped too early, expect sympathetic responses despite hypnosis; if both are stopped at the end, propofol may delay emergence. Rule of thumb for first-order decay: $t_{1/2}=\ln(2)/k$ and meaningful clinical recovery often requires on the order of 1–2 CSHTs, guiding the staggered timing of discontinuation.
educationalObjective: Explain context-sensitive half-times of propofol and remifentanil and how they shape emergence timelines.

questionText:
A 45-year-old ASA II man is undergoing a 3-hour laparoscopic colectomy with a circle system and active scavenging to wall vacuum. After IV induction and intubation, maintenance is desflurane 6% in air/oxygen at fresh gas flow (FGF) 3 L/min; end-tidal $CO_2$ is 34 mm Hg, MAP 78 mm Hg, and he is hemodynamically stable. The surgeon requests a deep plane for insufflation, and there are no contraindications to TIVA. You want to minimize the environmental impact of the anesthetic while maintaining adequate depth.

Which management change would most effectively reduce the greenhouse gas emissions of this case?

answers.text: Switch to total intravenous anesthesia (propofol infusion) with air/oxygen and discontinue inhaled agents
answers.explanation: Eliminating volatile anesthetics removes the major source of greenhouse emissions from the anesthetic; propofol has negligible direct global warming impact compared with halogenated agents. This yields a larger reduction than simply lowering FGF or switching to a lower-GWP volatile.

answers.text: Keep desflurane but reduce FGF to 0.5–1 L/min after equilibration
answers.explanation: Lowering FGF proportionally reduces volatile consumption, but desflurane’s very high GWP (~2540 $CO_2$e) means substantial emissions persist. This improves but does not outperform eliminating volatiles altogether.

answers.text: Switch to sevoflurane at 1 MAC with FGF 0.5–1 L/min and avoid $N_2O$
answers.explanation: Sevoflurane has a much lower GWP (~130 $CO_2$e) and low-flow anesthesia markedly decreases emissions, but volatile use still emits greenhouse gases. TIVA produces an even larger reduction by avoiding volatiles entirely.

answers.text: Add 50% $N_2O$ to reduce desflurane requirements and keep FGF at 2 L/min
answers.explanation: Although $N_2O$ lowers desflurane consumption, $N_2O$ itself has a high GWP (~298 $CO_2$e) and long atmospheric lifetime, often increasing the net footprint.

answers.text: Increase active scavenging vacuum to maximize waste-gas removal from the OR
answers.explanation: Scavenging protects staff from exposure but vents anesthetic gases to the environment; it does not decrease greenhouse emissions unless coupled to capture/recycling systems, which standard active scavenging is not.

didactic: Volatile anesthetics dominate the perioperative greenhouse footprint; choosing not to use them (TIVA) usually provides the largest reduction in emissions. If using inhaled agents, avoid desflurane (GWP100 ≈ 2540 $CO_2$e) and $N_2O$ (≈ 298), and prefer sevoflurane (≈ 130) or isoflurane (≈ 510) while minimizing FGF after equilibration. Volatile consumption scales with flow and concentration; a useful rule is $mL_{liquid}/h \approx 3 \times \text{FGF (L/min)} \times \text{vol\%}$, so cutting FGF from 2 to 0.5 L/min reduces agent use by ~75%. Active scavenging reduces occupational exposure but does not mitigate climate impact because gases are vented outdoors; only capture/recycling systems change that. Practical steps: avoid $N_2O$, avoid desflurane, use low-flow (0.5–1 L/min) circle anesthesia with vigilant monitoring of $FiO_2$, inspired agent, and $CO_2$ absorbent status, or choose TIVA when clinically appropriate. After induction/denitrogenation, lowering FGF and selecting a low-GWP agent substantially decrease emissions while maintaining stable anesthesia.
educationalObjective: Minimize environmental impact by understanding fresh gas flow, agent selection, and scavenging implications.

questionText: A 62-year-old man (90 kg) on lisinopril presents for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. After induction with propofol, fentanyl 100 mcg, and rocuronium, anesthesia is maintained with sevoflurane (end-tidal 2.3%) in air/O2 at FGF 2 L/min; no additional opioids have been given. Ten minutes later, just before incision, his BP is 78/46 mm Hg (MAP 57), HR 58 bpm, SpO2 99%, EtCO2 34 mm Hg, and processed EEG (BIS) is 32. The surgeon plans to incise in 2 minutes. Which is the most appropriate next step to improve blood pressure while maintaining adequate anesthesia?

answers.text: Reduce end-tidal sevoflurane to ~0.8–1.0 MAC and administer fentanyl 1 mcg/kg IV
answers.explanation: This balances hypnosis/analgesia: lowering volatile dose reverses vasodilation/myocardial depression driving hypotension, while an opioid blunts surgical nociception so anesthetic depth remains adequate. With a BIS of 32 and high ET sevo (age-adjusted >1 MAC), dose reduction plus opioid is the most direct way to restore MAP without under-anesthetizing.

answers.text: Administer phenylephrine 100 mcg IV and maintain the current anesthetic
answers.explanation: A vasopressor can transiently raise MAP, but maintaining excessive anesthetic depth (BIS 32, high ET sevo) perpetuates the root cause of hypotension. This approach risks masking volatile overdose and does not optimize balanced anesthesia.

answers.text: Increase sevoflurane to 2 MAC to ensure immobility at incision
answers.explanation: Further increasing volatile deepens vasodilation and myocardial depression, worsening hypotension. Adequate analgesia with reduced volatile is safer than escalating hypnotic dose when MAP is already low.

answers.text: Give 500 mL lactated Ringer’s and wait for recovery
answers.explanation: Crystalloid alone is slow and unlikely to correct volatile-induced hypotension in the next 2 minutes. It also fails to address excessive anesthetic depth and impending nociceptive stimulus.

answers.text: Switch to propofol TIVA (e.g., 150 mcg/kg/min) and discontinue sevoflurane
answers.explanation: Propofol also reduces SVR and contractility and often worsens hypotension, particularly immediately post-induction and in patients on ACE inhibitors. Swapping one vasodilatory hypnotic for another does not fix the hemodynamic problem or provide balanced analgesia.

didactic: Volatile anesthetics and propofol both decrease MAP via vasodilation and dose-dependent myocardial depression; opioids reduce MAC and blunt sympathetic responses with minimal effect on SVR. In hypotension with clear evidence of excessive depth (e.g., low BIS, high end-tidal volatile), first reduce the hypnotic/volatile dose and add analgesia rather than treating solely with vasopressors. Balanced anesthesia leverages adjuncts (opioids, ketamine, dexmedetomidine, regional) to allow lower hypnotic/volatile doses and more stable hemodynamics. A practical approach is to target ~0.7–1.0 age-adjusted MAC for hypnosis and add opioid just before noxious stimuli; consider low-dose vasopressor support if MAP remains low after correcting depth. For multiple agents, approximate total anesthetic effect with MAC fractions: $\text{MAC}_{\text{fraction}}\approx\sum \tfrac{ET\%}{\text{MAC}_{\text{agent}}}$; excessive combined fractions correlate with hypotension. Rule of thumb: if MAP is low and BIS is low, lighten the anesthetic and add analgesia; if MAP is low with appropriate depth, use vasoactive support and assess volume/reserve.
educationalObjective: Mitigate hypotension from volatiles or propofol using balanced anesthesia (opioids, adjuncts) and vasoactive support.

questionText: A 55-year-old man with biopsy-proven malignant hyperthermia susceptibility undergoes laparoscopic colectomy using TIVA: propofol TCI (target effect-site $C_e$ 3.5 mcg/mL, Schnider model) and remifentanil 0.15 mcg/kg/min. He is paralyzed with a rocuronium infusion (0/4 TOF at the orbicularis). For the first 90 minutes, the processed EEG index is 40–50. During pneumoperitoneum, the index rises to 70–75 with increased EMG activity; HR and BP remain stable on phenylephrine 0.5 mcg/min. End-tidal agent reads 0.0 MAC. The hand IV site looks slightly puffy and cool; the propofol syringe and pump display appear to be running normally. Which action best minimizes the immediate risk of intraoperative awareness in this patient?

answers.text: Deliver a propofol 1 mg/kg IV bolus via a confirmed patent IV and re-establish a dedicated hypnotic infusion (replace the infiltrated line).
answers.explanation: A prompt propofol bolus through a verified patent IV rapidly restores hypnosis (propofol $t_{1/2ke0}\approx2$–3 min) and addresses the most likely cause—failed drug delivery from IV infiltration. Re-establishing a reliable, dedicated line prevents recurrent underdosing and best reduces awareness risk.

answers.text: Increase remifentanil to 0.3 mcg/kg/min while maintaining the current propofol target.
answers.explanation: Opioids reduce nociception but do not ensure unconsciousness; raising remifentanil treats sympathetic responses yet does not correct inadequate hypnotic delivery. This choice risks awake paralysis if propofol is not reaching the patient.

answers.text: Administer midazolam 2 mg IV and continue the current infusions unchanged.
answers.explanation: A small benzodiazepine dose may provide anterograde amnesia but has unreliable and delayed hypnotic effect in this setting; it does not fix a delivery failure. Relying on midazolam while propofol is not reaching the patient risks awareness.

answers.text: Give an additional 50 mg rocuronium to suppress EMG and drive the processed EEG index <60.
answers.explanation: Neuromuscular blockade can reduce EMG artifact and lower the index numerically without increasing hypnosis. This masks movement and may falsely reassure while the patient remains conscious if hypnotic delivery is inadequate.

answers.text: Add N2O 50% to the carrier gas and continue the current TIVA rates.
answers.explanation: N2O is MH-safe but provides limited hypnotic effect and may worsen bowel distension in colorectal surgery. It does not address the likely infiltration and is insufficient to reliably prevent awareness during inadequate propofol delivery.

didactic: Awareness risk is higher with TIVA because there is no continuous end-tidal measure of hypnotic depth; prevention hinges on validated propofol regimens and rigorous delivery assurance. Use a dedicated IV for hypnotic infusion, visible tubing, anti-free-flow valves, appropriate occlusion alarms, and frequent site checks; infiltration may not trigger pump alarms. When light anesthesia is suspected during TIVA, the safest immediate step is to deliver a propofol bolus via a confirmed patent IV and promptly restore a reliable infusion; typical maintenance is propofol 100–200 mcg/kg/min or TCI $C_e$ 3–5 mcg/mL with an opioid. Processed EEG targets of 40–60 are useful adjuncts, but interpret with context: EMG, electrocautery, ketamine, and N2O can artifactually raise or alter the index, while neuromuscular blockade can lower it without increasing hypnosis. Remember propofol effect-site equilibration is rapid ($t_{1/2ke0}\approx2$–3 min), enabling effective rescue boluses of 0.5–1 mg/kg. Opioids and neuromuscular blockers do not prevent awareness; benzodiazepines are adjuncts, not a fix for delivery failure.
educationalObjective: Prevent awareness during TIVA with validated infusion regimens, vigilant pump checks, and processed EEG when appropriate.

questionText:
A 58-year-old man with a 7-cm frontal meningioma and 6-mm midline shift undergoes craniotomy. After bone flap removal, the dura appears tense and bulging. He is maintained on sevoflurane 1.2 MAC in air/O2 with a remifentanil infusion; head is elevated, PEEP is 0 cm H2O, and ventilation targets ETCO2 29–30 mm Hg (ABG PaCO2 31 mm Hg). Hemodynamics are stable (BP 128/72 mm Hg, HR 66 bpm). The surgeon requests a "softer" brain to facilitate dural opening.

Which change to the anesthetic maintenance regimen would best reduce intracranial pressure (ICP) and improve brain relaxation in this patient?

answers.text: Discontinue sevoflurane and maintain anesthesia with a propofol-based TIVA plus opioid
answers.explanation: Propofol lowers $CMRO_2$, causes cerebral vasoconstriction, and reduces $CBF$ and cerebral blood volume, thereby decreasing ICP, while preserving CO2 reactivity and autoregulation. Converting to propofol (or adding a propofol infusion and reducing volatile to ≤0.5 MAC) reliably improves brain relaxation in mass-lesion cases.

answers.text: Increase sevoflurane from 1.2 MAC to 1.8 MAC to further reduce $CMRO_2$
answers.explanation: At ≥1 MAC, volatile-induced cerebral vasodilation uncouples flow from metabolism, increasing $CBF$ and cerebral blood volume, which can raise ICP despite lower $CMRO_2$. Higher MAC also impairs autoregulation, worsening brain swelling.

answers.text: Switch to isoflurane at 1.0 MAC for its cerebroprotective profile
answers.explanation: All modern volatiles dose-dependently vasodilate cerebral vessels and can increase ICP; isoflurane is not superior to propofol for brain relaxation. Propofol better preserves autoregulation and lowers $CBF$/ICP via vasoconstriction.

answers.text: Add 50% N2O and reduce sevoflurane to 0.7 MAC to maintain depth with less volatile
answers.explanation: N2O increases $CBF$ and ICP via cerebral vasodilation and may worsen brain tension; it also risks pneumocephalus expansion. Reducing sevoflurane does not offset nitrous’ ICP-raising effect.

answers.text: Keep sevoflurane at 1.2 MAC and increase the remifentanil infusion substantially
answers.explanation: Opioids have minimal direct effect on $CMRO_2$ and $CBF$ and do not reliably lower ICP. Leaving the volatile unchanged maintains the primary driver of cerebral vasodilation and elevated ICP in this setting.

didactic: Volatile agents produce dose-dependent decreases in $CMRO_2$ but also direct cerebral vasodilation that increases $CBF$ and cerebral blood volume, raising ICP; at ≥~1 MAC this vasodilation can uncouple flow from metabolism. In contrast, propofol reduces $CMRO_2$ and causes cerebral vasoconstriction, lowering $CBF$ and ICP while preserving CO2 reactivity and cerebral autoregulation—properties that improve brain relaxation in mass lesions. A practical rule: for intracranial pathology with elevated ICP, prefer propofol-based TIVA or keep volatile ≤0.5 MAC and supplement with opioid/propofol to maintain depth. Avoid N2O because it increases $CBF$/ICP and can expand trapped air. CO2 reactivity is typically preserved with both propofol and volatiles, but excessive hyperventilation is a temporizing measure and risks ischemia; targeting PaCO2 ~30–35 mm Hg is common. Remember $CPP = MAP - ICP$; strategies that reduce ICP without compromising MAP best preserve cerebral perfusion. Volatiles also depress evoked potentials in a dose-dependent fashion, whereas propofol-based TIVA better supports neurophysiologic monitoring.
educationalObjective: Tailor maintenance for neurosurgery by comparing effects of volatiles versus propofol on CMRO₂, CBF, and ICP.

questionText:
A 72-year-old man (ASA III) is undergoing open inguinal hernia repair under general anesthesia with a circle system. Ten minutes after induction and just after skin incision, his BP rises from 110/65 to 160/85 mm Hg and HR from 65 to 95 bpm with tearing noted. He is mechanically ventilated (EtCO2 35 mm Hg). Fresh gas flow (FGF) is 1 L/min (50% O2/air). The sevoflurane vaporizer is set at 2.0%, and the monitor displays end-tidal sevoflurane 1.1% with age-adjusted MAC 0.8. Fentanyl 100 mcg was given 20 minutes earlier.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to rapidly achieve adequate anesthetic depth?

answers.text: Increase FGF to 6–8 L/min and raise the sevoflurane dial to target an age-adjusted end-tidal MAC of about 1.0–1.2 while monitoring hemodynamics.
answers.explanation: This directly titrates to brain-effect by using end-tidal MAC-age and speeds alveolar concentration change via higher FGF (shorter circuit time constant, $\tau=V/\text{FGF}$). It addresses inadequate volatile depth promptly and safely.

answers.text: Increase the sevoflurane dial to 3.5% while keeping FGF at 1 L/min until BP and HR normalize.
answers.explanation: Focusing on dial setting alone ignores that at low FGF the alveolar/end-tidal concentration will rise slowly; once it finally equilibrates, depth may overshoot and cause hypotension. Titration should be guided by end-tidal MAC-age, with FGF increased to change ET quickly.

answers.text: Administer labetalol 10 mg IV to treat hypertension without changing the anesthetic.
answers.explanation: This treats the symptom but leaves inadequate anesthetic depth (ET MAC-age 0.8) and risks awareness. First correct volatile depth using end-tidal MAC-age; adjuncts for hemodynamics can follow if needed.

answers.text: Give fentanyl 50 mcg IV and maintain current vaporizer and flows.
answers.explanation: Opioid can blunt nociception, but the volatile depth is subtherapeutic for this 72-year-old (ET MAC-age 0.8). Correcting age-adjusted ET MAC promptly is primary; opioid can be added as needed once volatile depth is adequate.

answers.text: Wait 3–5 minutes for the current dial setting to equilibrate before intervening.
answers.explanation: At FGF 1 L/min, the circle time constant is long ($\tau=V/\text{FGF}$), so end-tidal concentration will change slowly. Given active sympathetic responses, delaying intervention is unsafe; increase FGF and titrate to ET MAC-age now.

didactic: End-tidal volatile concentration is the best readily available proxy for brain partial pressure; titration should be based on end-tidal MAC adjusted for age and clinical signs, not vaporizer dial setting. MAC decreases roughly 6% per decade after age 40, so older adults require less agent; a practical target during moderate stimulation is ET MAC-age ≈0.8–1.2. When a rapid change in anesthetic depth is needed, increase both vaporizer concentration and fresh gas flow to accelerate alveolar concentration change; the circle system time constant follows $\tau = V/\text{FGF}$, so higher FGF shortens $\tau$. Hemodynamic or somatic signs (tachycardia, hypertension, lacrimation, movement) suggest inadequate depth or analgesia and should prompt adjustment of end-tidal MAC-age before relying on antihypertensives. Uptake factors (cardiac output, solubility, alveolar ventilation) affect how quickly end-tidal approaches the dialed concentration, reinforcing the need to use the measured ET value. When multiple agents are used (e.g., N2O plus volatile), MAC fractions are additive; titrate the sum to the clinical context.
educationalObjective: Titrate volatile depth using end-tidal MAC adjusted for age and clinical signs rather than dial setting alone.

questionText: A 40-year-old, 80-kg patient is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy with a circle system. After denitrogenation for 10 minutes at 4 L/min with FiO2 0.5, you reduce fresh gas flow (FGF) to 0.5 L/min using O2/air (FiO2 0.5) and sevoflurane 2.2%. Twenty minutes later, continuous gas monitoring shows: inspired O2 falling from 0.50 to 0.32, inspired N2 rising to 0.12, end-tidal CO2 35 mm Hg, and stable tidal volumes without evidence of a circuit leak; SpO2 remains 100% on PEEP 5 cm H2O. You wish to continue low-flow anesthesia. Which adjustment is most appropriate to maintain safe oxygenation now?

answers.text: Increase FiO2 to 0.8 while maintaining FGF at 0.5 L/min
answers.explanation: At low flows, oxygen delivery to the circuit equals $FiO_2 \times FGF$. With FGF 0.5 L/min, raising FiO2 to 0.8 provides 0.4 L/min (400 mL/min) of O2, exceeding adult $\dot V O_2$ (~200–250 mL/min) and countering dilution from tissue N2 washout, while preserving low-flow anesthesia.

answers.text: Increase FGF to 2 L/min for the remainder of the case while keeping FiO2 0.5
answers.explanation: This would increase O2 delivery and wash out N2, but unnecessarily abandons low-flow anesthesia; the problem can be solved by increasing FiO2 at the same low FGF. Brief re-denitrogenation is reasonable if needed, but maintaining high FGF for the rest of the case is not required.

answers.text: Add 50% N2O at the same FGF to maintain MAC while reducing O2 needs
answers.explanation: N2O reduces volatile MAC but does not reduce metabolic O2 consumption and displaces O2 in the carrier gas. At low flows, waning N2O uptake later in the case can further lower inspired O2, worsening the problem.

answers.text: Increase sevoflurane concentration to 3.5% while maintaining current FGF and FiO2
answers.explanation: Changing volatile concentration does not increase O2 delivery ($FiO_2 \times FGF$). The falling inspired O2 is due to O2 supply being near $\dot V O_2$ and dilution by N2 washout, not inadequate anesthetic depth.

answers.text: Replace the CO2 absorbent and perform a system leak test before changing gas settings
answers.explanation: There is no evidence of absorbent exhaustion (ETCO2 normal) or a significant leak (stable volumes/pressures). Immediate correction of inspired O2 is safer; leak checks and absorbent changes are not the primary issue causing the FiO2 decline.

didactic: In low-flow anesthesia, oxygen delivery to the circuit is $\text{O2 inflow} = FiO_2 \times FGF$ (in L/min), which must exceed the patient’s metabolic O2 consumption ($\dot V O_2$ ~200–250 mL/min in adults) with a safety margin. Early in maintenance, ongoing tissue N2 washout can dilute circuit gases and drive inspired O2 down, especially when $FiO_2 \times FGF$ approaches $\dot V O_2$ (e.g., 0.5 L/min × 0.5 = 250 mL/min). Practical rules: when FGF \le 0.5–0.6 L/min, set FiO2 high (often 0.7–1.0) and closely track inspired O2; use continuous agent and O2 analyzers, and ensure a leak-free circle. If inspired O2 drifts down, first increase FiO2 (and/or briefly increase FGF to re-denitrogenate) rather than abandoning low-flow. N2O does not spare O2 consumption and can worsen FiO2 trends at low flow as its uptake wanes. With modern, non–strong-base absorbents (e.g., Amsorb), sevoflurane is safe at low flows; the limiting factor is oxygen supply, not compound A.
educationalObjective: Use low fresh gas flows safely during volatile maintenance with continuous gas monitoring and leak-free circuits.

questionText: A 72-year-old man with benign prostatic hyperplasia and well-controlled hypertension undergoes laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair under general anesthesia. He received neostigmine 3 mg with glycopyrrolate 0.6 mg for reversal and 2 L of crystalloid; no neuraxial anesthesia was used. Ninety minutes after arrival to the PACU, his BP is 182/96 mm Hg and HR is 112 bpm. He is afebrile, SpO2 98% on 2 L/min nasal cannula, and RR 16/min. He is alert, denies incisional pain, and repeatedly states he “really needs to urinate.” Exam reveals a tender, distended suprapubic area. A bedside bladder scan measures 850 mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate intervention to control his hypertension and tachycardia?

answers.text: Straight catheterization to decompress the bladder
answers.explanation: Bladder distention triggers a sympathetic surge (tachycardia and hypertension); prompt decompression directly treats the cause and rapidly normalizes hemodynamics. Volumes >400–600 mL on bladder scan typically warrant catheterization, especially in high-risk patients (BPH, anticholinergics, opioids).

answers.text: Labetalol 10 mg IV
answers.explanation: This treats the numbers but not the cause; masking the sympathetic response without relieving obstruction leaves the precipitant unaddressed and risks urinary complications.

answers.text: Hydromorphone 0.5 mg IV
answers.explanation: Opioids are appropriate for pain-mediated hypertension, but this patient denies incisional pain and has classic urinary retention. Opioids may worsen retention and add sedation/respiratory risk.

answers.text: Dexmedetomidine infusion 0.2–0.4 mcg/kg/h
answers.explanation: Useful for withdrawal-related sympathetic activation, but the presentation (suprapubic fullness, large bladder volume) indicates urinary retention, which sedation will not correct.

answers.text: Administer an additional 500 mL crystalloid bolus and observe
answers.explanation: Additional fluids can worsen bladder distention. In established postoperative urinary retention, timely decompression is indicated rather than watchful waiting.

didactic: In the PACU, new-onset hypertension and tachycardia should prompt a search for reversible sympathetic stimuli: pain, hypoxia/hypercarbia, shivering, bladder distention, or withdrawal. Postoperative urinary retention is common with BPH, anticholinergics (e.g., glycopyrrolate), opioids, and large fluid loads. Bladder scan volumes >400–600 mL generally merit catheterization; decompression rapidly reduces the sympathetic surge and improves vitals. Treat the cause first rather than reflexively administering antihypertensives or sedatives, which may mask symptoms and delay definitive care. Opioids are appropriate when pain is the driver but can worsen retention. For suspected withdrawal, targeted agents (e.g., benzodiazepines for alcohol, clonidine/dexmedetomidine for sympatholysis) are preferred. A practical rule: identify and reverse the stimulus; treat the numbers only if hemodynamics remain unsafe after addressing the cause.
educationalObjective: Control hypertension and tachycardia due to pain, bladder distention, or withdrawal with targeted therapy.

questionText: A 54-year-old man (95 kg, BMI 32) is in the PACU 15 minutes after laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia with rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. The last rocuronium dose (20 mg) was given 35 minutes before extubation. No reversal was administered. He is arousable but weak with shallow respirations (RR 8/min), intermittent upper-airway obstruction relieved by a jaw thrust, SpO2 94% on 6 L/min via simple face mask, and nasal capnography shows elevated EtCO2. Pupils are mid-size and reactive. Quantitative acceleromyography at the adductor pollicis shows a TOF count of 4/4 with a TOF ratio of $0.45$. Hemodynamics are stable. Which intervention is the most appropriate to reverse the underlying cause of his hypoventilation?

answers.text: Administer sugammadex 2 mg/kg IV now
answers.explanation: A TOF ratio $<0.9$ after rocuronium indicates residual blockade; with TOF count 4 and TOF ratio $0.45$ (moderate block), sugammadex $2\,\text{mg/kg}$ rapidly restores neuromuscular transmission to TOF ratio $\ge 0.9$ within minutes.

answers.text: Administer sugammadex 4 mg/kg IV now
answers.explanation: $4\,\text{mg/kg}$ is indicated for deep block (TOF count 0 with post-tetanic count 1–2). It will work but is not the most appropriate dose for moderate residual block and represents unnecessary overtreatment.

answers.text: Administer neostigmine 50 mcg/kg IV with glycopyrrolate 10 mcg/kg
answers.explanation: While neostigmine can reverse shallow–moderate block when TOF count is 4, it is slower and less reliable at a TOF ratio of $\approx 0.45$ and has a ceiling effect; in a symptomatic PACU patient after rocuronium, sugammadex provides faster, more predictable reversal.

answers.text: Apply BiPAP and observe
answers.explanation: Noninvasive ventilation may temporize hypoventilation but does not treat residual neuromuscular blockade and risks aspiration in a weak patient; definitive reversal is indicated.

answers.text: Administer naloxone 0.4 mg IV
answers.explanation: Opioid-induced hypoventilation would not explain a quantitative TOF ratio of $0.45$. Naloxone would not correct neuromuscular transmission and may precipitate pain and hypertension.

didactic: Residual neuromuscular blockade is common and clinically important; safe recovery requires a quantitative TOF ratio $\ge 0.9$ (ideally $\ge 1.0$ with acceleromyography). Clinical tests (head lift, tidal volume) are insensitive to residual block. Depth-specific reversal is key: for rocuronium/vecuronium, give sugammadex $2\,\text{mg/kg}$ for moderate block (TOF count $\ge 2$), $4\,\text{mg/kg}$ for deep block (TOF count 0 with PTC 1–2), and $16\,\text{mg/kg}$ for immediate reversal after large intubating doses. Neostigmine $40$–$70\,\mu\text{g/kg}$ with an antimuscarinic (e.g., glycopyrrolate $10$–$20\,\mu\text{g/kg}$) requires a TOF count of 4 and has a ceiling effect with slower, less predictable recovery; it should not be used for deep block. In a symptomatic PACU patient, provide airway support and oxygen while administering the appropriate reversal based on quantitative monitoring. Dose sugammadex to actual body weight and avoid in severe renal failure when possible, as the drug–complex is renally excreted.
educationalObjective: Detect residual neuromuscular blockade with quantitative monitoring and administer appropriate reversal or support ventilation.

questionText:
A 64-year-old man is 30 minutes post-extubation in the PACU after an uneventful laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He received fentanyl 200 mcg and hydromorphone 0.8 mg during the case. He is somnolent, arouses to voice, answers briefly, and falls back asleep. Vitals: BP 138/78 mm Hg, HR 58/min, RR 6/min, SpO2 86% on room air. Pupils are 2 mm and reactive; lungs are clear without crackles or wheeze; there is no chest pain. Nasal capnography shows ETCO2 56 mm Hg with low-amplitude waveforms. An ABG on room air shows: pH 7.25, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, PaO2 55 mm Hg. Using the alveolar gas equation $P_{AO_2}=FiO_2(P_b-P_{H_2O})-\frac{PaCO_2}{R}$, his A–a gradient is approximately normal for age (expected ≈ age/4 + 4 ≈ 20 mm Hg).

Which intervention is the most appropriate next step in management?

answers.text: Titrate IV naloxone in 20–40 mcg boluses to restore adequate ventilation while monitoring for acute pain and renarcotization
answers.explanation: Somnolence, bradypnea, miotic pupils, elevated PaCO2, and a near-normal A–a gradient indicate opioid-induced hypoventilation. Targeted reversal with small, titrated doses of naloxone addresses the cause (ventilatory depression) rather than only treating hypoxemia.

answers.text: Initiate CPAP at 10 cm H2O with 40% O2 to treat presumed postoperative atelectasis
answers.explanation: Atelectasis causes V/Q mismatch with an increased A–a gradient; CPAP can help when that is the mechanism. Here the normal A–a gradient and marked hypercapnia point to pure hypoventilation, which CPAP alone will not correct.

answers.text: Administer IV furosemide 20 mg for suspected cardiogenic pulmonary edema
answers.explanation: Pulmonary edema presents with crackles, pink frothy sputum, and an elevated A–a gradient on ABG. Clear lungs and a normal A–a gradient make edema unlikely; diuresis does not address opioid-induced ventilatory depression.

answers.text: Order CT pulmonary angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism
answers.explanation: Acute PE typically increases dead space (low ETCO2 relative to PaCO2) and raises the A–a gradient; patients are usually tachycardic and tachypneic. Immediate stabilization and reversal of hypoventilation take precedence, and the data do not support PE here.

answers.text: Perform alveolar recruitment maneuvers and increase PEEP to improve oxygenation
answers.explanation: Recruitment/PEEP treats atelectasis-related shunt/V–Q mismatch (elevated A–a gradient). The primary problem is opioid-induced hypoventilation with a normal A–a gradient; improving oxygenation without restoring ventilation risks worsening hypercapnia.

didactic: A stepwise approach to PACU hypoxemia distinguishes hypoventilation from V/Q mismatch, shunt, and edema. The A–a gradient helps: hypoventilation has a normal A–a gradient, while V/Q mismatch, shunt (atelectasis), edema, and PE elevate it. Use the alveolar gas equation $P_{AO_2}=FiO_2(P_b-P_{H_2O})-\frac{PaCO_2}{R}$ (with $R\approx0.8$) and the rule of thumb for expected A–a: ≈ age/4 + 4 (mm Hg). Opioid-induced hypoventilation presents with somnolence, bradypnea, elevated PaCO2, and often miotic pupils; treatment is restoration of ventilation—titrate naloxone in small aliquots (e.g., 20–40 mcg IV) to avoid abrupt pain and hypertension, with monitoring for renarcotization. Atelectasis is the most common postoperative cause of hypoxemia but typically raises the A–a gradient and responds to recruitment/CPAP, incentive spirometry, and early mobilization. PE often shows tachycardia, pleuritic pain, increased dead space (low ETCO2 with normal or rising PaCO2), and an increased A–a gradient; pulmonary edema features crackles and responds to PEEP and, when cardiogenic, diuresis. Always provide supportive oxygen and airway maneuvers, but target therapy to the mechanism suggested by physiology.
educationalObjective: Evaluate hypoxemia using a stepwise differential (atelectasis, hypoventilation, PE, edema) and targeted treatments.

questionText: A 78-year-old man with hypertension and mild cognitive impairment undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy under sevoflurane anesthesia. He received acetaminophen 1 g and fentanyl 100 mcg intraoperatively; neuromuscular blockade was reversed and extubation was uneventful. Ten minutes after PACU arrival he is agitated, pulling at his IV, and not following commands. Vitals: BP 165/95 mm Hg, HR 105/min, RR 18/min, SpO2 97% on 3 L/min O2 by nasal cannula. Nasal capnography shows EtCO2 38 mm Hg. Point-of-care glucose is 110 mg/dL; temperature is 36.6°C. He grimaces with light palpation near the trocar sites and moans when repositioned. Pupils are equal/reactive; no focal deficits; Foley is draining clear urine. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management to address his condition?

answers.text: Provide verbal reorientation, ensure glasses/hearing aids are in place, and titrate small IV opioid doses (e.g., fentanyl 25 mcg) to treat pain while avoiding benzodiazepines
answers.explanation: This presentation is consistent with emergence delirium likely exacerbated by pain. First-line management is nonpharmacologic reorientation and correction of reversible precipitants (pain, sensory deprivation), using small, titrated opioids while avoiding deliriogenic sedatives.

answers.text: Administer IV midazolam 2 mg to calm agitation
answers.explanation: Benzodiazepines are deliriogenic in older adults and can worsen or prolong delirium; they are reserved for specific indications (e.g., alcohol withdrawal). This choice targets symptoms but exacerbates the underlying problem.

answers.text: Start a dexmedetomidine infusion at 0.2–0.7 mcg/kg/h for sedation
answers.explanation: Dexmedetomidine is helpful when agitation endangers safety or persists after nonpharmacologic measures and analgesia, but it is not the initial step for typical emergence delirium. It also carries bradycardia/hypotension risk in this patient.

answers.text: Give haloperidol 5 mg IV now and apply physical restraints
answers.explanation: High-dose haloperidol increases risk of QT prolongation and extrapyramidal effects and is not first-line. If needed for refractory agitation, use low doses (e.g., 0.5–1 mg IV) after addressing pain and employing reorientation.

answers.text: Obtain an emergent noncontrast head CT
answers.explanation: In the absence of focal deficits, trauma, or unexplained vital sign derangements, immediate neuroimaging is low yield. Reversible PACU causes (pain, hypoxia/hypercarbia, hypoglycemia, retention) should be addressed first.

didactic: Emergence delirium in the PACU often reflects a combination of acute brain dysfunction and reversible precipitants such as pain, hypoxia/hypercarbia, and sensory deprivation. Initial management prioritizes ABCs and correctable causes: ensure adequate oxygenation/ventilation (SpO2 > 94%, EtCO2 near baseline), check glucose, treat pain with multimodal and titrated IV opioids, and provide reorientation with familiar aids (glasses, hearing aids). Avoid deliriogenic medications—especially benzodiazepines, anticholinergics, and meperidine—unless specifically indicated. If agitation persists or threatens safety despite these steps, consider non-deliriogenic sedation with dexmedetomidine (e.g., 0.2–0.7 mcg/kg/h) or low-dose antipsychotics (haloperidol 0.5–1 mg IV) while monitoring QTc and hemodynamics. Hypoactive delirium presents with inattention and lethargy; management is similar—reorientation, sleep hygiene, early mobilization, and pain control—while minimizing sedatives. Practical rule: treat pain first, talk first, and sedate last, using the least deliriogenic agent when necessary.
educationalObjective: Identify emergence delirium or hypoactive delirium and manage with reorientation, pain control, and minimal deliriogenic drugs.

questionText:
A 56-year-old man (BMI 36) with obstructive sleep apnea (uses home CPAP) undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. Intraoperatively he received fentanyl 200 mcg and hydromorphone 0.6 mg, with the last opioid given 30 minutes before PACU arrival. In PACU: BP 145/85 mm Hg, HR 90 bpm, RR 10/min with shallow breaths, SpO2 99% on 2 L/min nasal cannula, and end-tidal CO2 monitoring has not yet been applied. On the Pasero Opioid-Induced Sedation Scale he is a 2 (slightly drowsy, easily aroused). When awakened, he reports pain 7/10. The nurse asks you to start a PCA.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to initiate analgesia while minimizing the risk of oversedation in this patient?

answers.text: Start hydromorphone PCA demand-only (0.2 mg/dose, 10-min lockout, no basal infusion; reasonable 4-h limit), add scheduled non-opioids (e.g., IV acetaminophen ± ketorolac if no contraindication), and institute continuous capnography in addition to pulse oximetry.
answers.explanation: For an opioid-naïve, OSA patient on supplemental O2 with borderline ventilation, demand-only PCA plus multimodal analgesia reduces opioid requirements and avoids background opioid. Continuous capnography detects hypoventilation earlier than oximetry when supplemental O2 is used, enhancing safety.

answers.text: Start hydromorphone PCA with a 0.2 mg demand dose and a 0.4 mg/h basal infusion; pulse oximetry alone is adequate monitoring.
answers.explanation: Basal infusions increase the risk of opioid-induced ventilatory depression, especially in opioid-naïve or OSA patients. Relying on pulse oximetry alone while on supplemental O2 can delay recognition of hypoventilation.

answers.text: Administer an additional hydromorphone 1 mg IV loading dose to "get ahead of pain," then start demand-only PCA; monitor with pulse oximetry.
answers.explanation: Stacking more opioid in a patient who is drowsy with RR 10/min increases risk of respiratory depression. Supplemental O2 may mask hypoventilation on oximetry, so further loading is unsafe and capnography is preferred.

answers.text: Stop supplemental oxygen to better detect hypoventilation on pulse oximetry, then start morphine PCA demand-only with a low lockout interval.
answers.explanation: Withholding oxygen to "unmask" hypoventilation is unsafe in OSA and may precipitate hypoxemia; monitoring should be improved (capnography), not oxygen withdrawn. A shorter lockout invites dose stacking if the patient is somnolent but in pain.

answers.text: Defer PCA initiation and use a ketamine infusion (0.2 mg/kg/h) as the sole analgesic until fully awake; routine oximetry is sufficient.
answers.explanation: Low-dose ketamine is an effective adjunct but is rarely used as sole analgesia for moderate postoperative pain. It should complement, not replace, opioid-sparing multimodal therapy, and high-risk patients still benefit from capnography.

didactic: Opioid-naïve patients with OSA are at heightened risk of opioid-induced ventilatory impairment, particularly when residual intraoperative opioids are present. Avoid background (basal) PCA infusions in such patients; use demand-only dosing with typical settings (e.g., hydromorphone 0.2 mg/dose, 8–10 min lockout, reasonable hourly or 4-h limits). Combine PCA with multimodal analgesia (scheduled acetaminophen; NSAIDs if not contraindicated; consider regional/local, gabapentinoids, or low-dose ketamine as adjuncts) to lower opioid requirements. Supplemental O2 can mask hypoventilation on pulse oximetry, so continuous capnography is recommended for high-risk patients or those receiving supplemental O2. Monitor sedation and respiration frequently early after PACU arrival; increasing sedation often precedes respiratory depression. Practical physiology: hypoventilation reduces alveolar ventilation $\dot V_A = (V_T - V_D) \times f$, causing $\uparrow\,PaCO_2$ well before desaturation on O2. Resume the patient’s home CPAP when resting or asleep, and have naloxone readily available for oversedation.
educationalObjective: Initiate multimodal analgesia and PCA safely in PACU, including monitoring for oversedation.

questionText:
A 68-year-old woman is in the PACU 20 minutes after total knee arthroplasty performed with a combined spinal-epidural. An epidural infusion of ropivacaine 0.2% was started at 6 mL/hr in the OR. She reports lightheadedness. Vitals: BP 72/40 mm Hg, HR 48/min, RR 14/min, SpO2 99% on 2 L/min NC, T 36.6°C. She is warm and well perfused with brisk capillary refill; lungs are clear; surgical dressing is dry. Sensory block to cold is at T4. Point-of-care ultrasound shows an IVC diameter of 1.8 cm with <15% respiratory variation and normal LV systolic function without B-lines. Estimated blood loss was 150 mL; she received 1.5 L crystalloid intraoperatively and has made 200 mL urine. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management for her hypotension?

Note: $MAP = CO \times SVR$

answers.text: Administer 500 mL lactated Ringer’s bolus
answers.explanation: Misconception: equating all postoperative hypotension with hypovolemia. Minimal IVC collapsibility (<15%) and warm extremities argue against fluid responsiveness; additional crystalloid is unlikely to raise MAP and may cause fluid overload without addressing neuraxial vasodilation.

answers.text: Give 100 mcg phenylephrine IV bolus
answers.explanation: Phenylephrine increases SVR but can worsen reflex or neuraxial-related bradycardia and reduce CO. In this vasodilatory, bradycardic state from high sympathetic block, a mixed α/β agent is preferred to support both SVR and HR/CO.

answers.text: Give 8 mg ephedrine IV bolus
answers.explanation: Neuraxial sympathectomy has produced vasodilation (low SVR) and relative venous pooling with bradycardia; ultrasound suggests she is not fluid responsive. Ephedrine’s mixed α/β effects increase SVR and HR/CO, countering both components and improving $MAP = CO \times SVR$ more appropriately than a pure α-agonist.

answers.text: Start norepinephrine at 0.05 mcg/kg/min
answers.explanation: Norepinephrine is appropriate for refractory vasoplegia or distributive shock, but a rapid-acting bolus pressor is the immediate first step for transient spinal/epidural-induced hypotension; an infusion may be considered if hypotension persists after boluses and epidural adjustment.

answers.text: Administer 10 mg furosemide IV
answers.explanation: This assumes cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which is unsupported here (clear lungs, normal LV function, warm extremities). Diuresis would reduce preload further and likely worsen hypotension.

didactic: Postoperative hypotension requires rapid classification into hypovolemic, vasodilatory, or cardiogenic patterns using history, exam, and point-of-care data. Spinal/epidural sympathectomy decreases SVR and venous return, often with bradycardia from unopposed vagal tone; patients appear warm with wide pulse pressures and preserved oxygenation. When ultrasound suggests the patient is not fluid responsive (e.g., IVC diameter ~1.5–2.0 cm with low collapsibility in a spontaneously breathing patient), vasopressors are preferred over empiric fluids. Choice of agent matters: ephedrine (mixed α/β) is favored when hypotension coexists with bradycardia because it supports both SVR and CO, whereas phenylephrine (pure α) may exacerbate bradycardia and reduce CO. Norepinephrine infusions are reserved for persistent or severe vasoplegia (e.g., refractory neuraxial block, sepsis) after initial boluses and addressing reversible causes (e.g., reducing or holding the epidural). Remember $MAP = CO \times SVR$; target the limiting variable while avoiding therapies (excess fluid or diuretics) that worsen the underlying physiology.
educationalObjective: Manage hypotension by distinguishing hypovolemia, vasodilation, and cardiogenic causes and giving appropriate fluids or vasoactives.

questionText: A 62-year-old man is in the PACU 10 minutes after an uncomplicated laparoscopic cholecystectomy under sevoflurane anesthesia with fentanyl. He is awake, complaining of feeling cold, and has vigorous shivering. Vitals: T 35.2 °C, HR 108/min, BP 160/88 mm Hg, RR 20/min, SpO2 93% on 2 L/min nasal cannula. He has a history of stable coronary artery disease. You apply a forced-air warming blanket and warm IV fluids. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic therapy to control his shivering and reduce oxygen consumption?

answers.text: Administer IV meperidine 12.5–25 mg
answers.explanation: Meperidine has a unique anti-shivering effect (kappa-opioid and central monoaminergic/α2 actions) at low doses, rapidly suppressing postanesthetic shivering and reducing the associated 2–3× increase in $\dot{V}_{O2}$. It is first-line in PACU and pairs well with active warming.

answers.text: Administer IV clonidine 75 mcg
answers.explanation: Clonidine (α2-agonist) lowers the shivering threshold and can be effective, but onset may be slower and it risks hypotension/bradycardia; meperidine is generally preferred as initial therapy in PACU.

answers.text: Administer IV naloxone 0.04 mg
answers.explanation: Naloxone reverses analgesia and can exacerbate sympathetic activation; it does not treat thermoregulatory shivering and may worsen pain and myocardial oxygen demand.

answers.text: Administer IV ondansetron 4 mg
answers.explanation: 5-HT3 antagonists have inconsistent, modest benefit for shivering and are not first-line. They may be considered adjuncts but are inferior to meperidine for rapid control.

answers.text: Administer IV flumazenil 0.2 mg
answers.explanation: Flumazenil reverses benzodiazepines and has no specific anti-shivering effect. Postanesthetic shivering is thermoregulatory, most often from hypothermia/redistribution, not benzodiazepine-related.

didactic: Postanesthetic shivering is common in the PACU, usually from hypothermia and central thermoregulatory reset after volatile anesthetics and redistribution. It can increase oxygen consumption and CO2 production by 2–3×, raising myocardial oxygen demand—important in patients with limited cardiac reserve. First-line management is active rewarming (forced-air warming, warmed IV fluids) plus an effective anti-shivering drug. Meperidine 12.5–25 mg IV rapidly suppresses shivering via kappa-opioid and central monoaminergic/α2 mechanisms with minimal sedation at low doses. α2-agonists (e.g., clonidine ~1–2 mcg/kg IV or dexmedetomidine) also reduce the shivering threshold but may cause hypotension/bradycardia. Other agents (tramadol, magnesium, 5-HT3 antagonists) have variable efficacy and are typically adjuncts. Use caution with meperidine in the elderly, renal failure, or patients on serotonergic drugs due to normeperidine accumulation and serotonin syndrome risk.
educationalObjective: Recognize and treat shivering with active warming and drugs such as meperidine or clonidine.

questionText:
A 24-year-old man undergoes intramedullary nailing of a femoral shaft fracture under general anesthesia with sevoflurane and a single dose of succinylcholine for rapid-sequence induction. He remains intubated and is transferred to the PACU on volume-controlled ventilation (VT 7 mL/kg IBW, RR 12/min, FiO2 0.4, PEEP 5 cm H2O). Fifteen minutes later, the end-tidal CO2 rises from 36 to 58 mm Hg despite increasing RR to 22/min; arterial blood gas shows pH 7.18, PaCO2 72 mm Hg. Heart rate is 148/min, BP 165/95 mm Hg, temperature 39.6°C, and diffuse rigidity is noted with cola-colored urine in the Foley bag. Serum K+ just resulted at 6.1 mEq/L.

Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step?

answers.text: Administer dantrolene $2.5\ \text{mg/kg}$ IV immediately and hyperventilate with 100% O2 while initiating active cooling
answers.explanation: Rising $\text{ETCO}_2$ unresponsive to increased minute ventilation, generalized rigidity, hyperthermia, acidosis, and hyperkalemia after volatile/succinylcholine exposure are classic for malignant hyperthermia. Immediate therapy is dantrolene $2.5\ \text{mg/kg}$ IV (repeat to effect, up to $10\ \text{mg/kg}$), 100% O2 with aggressive hyperventilation, and active cooling, along with treatment of hyperkalemia and acidosis.

answers.text: Start an esmolol infusion to control adrenergic hyperactivity (suspected thyroid storm)
answers.explanation: Thyroid storm presents with fever and tachyarrhythmias but typically lacks severe hypercarbia, muscle rigidity, and hyperkalemia. Beta-blockade does not treat the pathologic sarcoplasmic $\text{Ca}^{2+}$ release of malignant hyperthermia and would delay life-saving dantrolene.

answers.text: Administer propylthiouracil followed by iodine and hydrocortisone
answers.explanation: This sequence is appropriate for thyroid storm (thionamide first, then iodine after 1 hour, plus glucocorticoids), not for malignant hyperthermia. The patient’s refractory hypercarbia, rigidity, and recent succinylcholine/volatile exposure point away from thyroid storm.

answers.text: Treat the hyperthermia with acetaminophen and surface cooling alone
answers.explanation: In malignant hyperthermia, heat generation is non–pyrogen mediated from uncontrolled skeletal muscle metabolism; antipyretics are ineffective. Cooling is adjunctive but must not delay dantrolene and definitive MH management.

answers.text: Administer IV calcium chloride immediately for hyperkalemia as the primary intervention
answers.explanation: Calcium can temporize membrane instability in life-threatening hyperkalemia, but it does not address the cause. In malignant hyperthermia, prioritize dantrolene and hyperventilation with 100% O2; treat hyperkalemia concurrently (e.g., insulin/dextrose, bicarbonate).

didactic: Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is triggered by volatile anesthetics and succinylcholine and classically presents with rapidly rising $\text{ETCO}_2$ despite increased minute ventilation, tachycardia, generalized rigidity, mixed metabolic–respiratory acidosis, hyperkalemia, and hyperthermia (often a late sign). Immediate management is disease-specific: stop triggers, hyperventilate with 100% O2, and give dantrolene $2.5\ \text{mg/kg}$ IV, repeating to effect (up to $10\ \text{mg/kg}$), followed by maintenance dosing (e.g., $1\ \text{mg/kg}$ every 4–6 h for 24 h) due to risk of recrudescence. Initiate active cooling, treat hyperkalemia (insulin/dextrose, bicarbonate; avoid calcium channel blockers with dantrolene), correct acidosis, and manage arrhythmias with amiodarone or lidocaine. By contrast, thyroid storm presents with fever, agitation, and tachyarrhythmias without marked hypercarbia or rigidity; treatment is beta-blockade (e.g., esmolol), a thionamide (PTU or methimazole), iodine given after the thionamide, glucocorticoids, volume resuscitation, and cooling (avoid aspirin). A practical rule: “Unexplained rising $\text{ETCO}_2$ + rigidity + acidosis/hyperkalemia after volatile/succinylcholine = MH until proven otherwise—give dantrolene now.” Early recognition and protocolized therapy markedly reduce morbidity and mortality.
educationalObjective: Recognize postoperative malignant hyperthermia or thyroid storm and initiate disease-specific protocols promptly.

questionText: A 38-year-old nonsmoking woman with a history of motion sickness undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy under sevoflurane anesthesia with perioperative opioids. She received dexamethasone 8 mg IV at induction and ondansetron 4 mg IV at skin closure. In the PACU 20 minutes after arrival she is actively retching despite promethazine 12.5 mg IV given 20 minutes ago. Vitals: BP 122/70 mm Hg, HR 84 bpm, RR 14/min, SpO2 98% on room air; she is alert and protecting her airway. A preoperative ECG showed $QT_c = 430\,\text{ms}$. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to treat her PONV?

answers.text: Administer haloperidol 1 mg IV
answers.explanation: After inadequate response to prophylaxis with a 5-HT3 antagonist and steroid and failed rescue with an H1 antihistamine, a different class is indicated; low-dose haloperidol (0.5–1 mg IV) is effective for refractory PONV with minimal sedation when $QT_c$ is not prolonged.

answers.text: Repeat ondansetron 4 mg IV now
answers.explanation: Repeating a 5-HT3 antagonist shortly after prophylaxis offers limited benefit due to class redundancy; guidelines favor switching to a different class for rescue within 6 hours.

answers.text: Apply a transdermal scopolamine patch
answers.explanation: Scopolamine has a delayed onset (hours), making it suboptimal for acute rescue of active emesis in the PACU.

answers.text: Administer propofol 20 mg IV for its antiemetic effect
answers.explanation: Small propofol boluses can transiently reduce nausea but provide short-lived benefit and risk oversedation/airway events; pharmacologic rescue with a different antiemetic class is preferred.

answers.text: Give aprepitant 40 mg PO now
answers.explanation: NK1 antagonists are effective for prophylaxis when given preoperatively; oral aprepitant has delayed onset and limited utility for immediate PACU rescue.

didactic: Rescue therapy for PONV should use an agent from a different pharmacologic class than those used for prophylaxis, especially within the first 6 hours postoperatively. After 5-HT3 antagonist and corticosteroid prophylaxis, effective rescue options include dopamine antagonists (droperidol, haloperidol, metoclopramide) or antihistamines/anticholinergics. Low-dose haloperidol (0.5–1 mg IV) is a reasonable choice for refractory PONV, providing meaningful relief with minimal sedation; monitor for QT prolongation and extrapyramidal symptoms, particularly if $QT_c$ > 450–470 ms or with other QT-prolonging drugs. Transdermal scopolamine is useful for prevention or delayed PONV but has a slow onset, limiting value in acute rescue. Repeating the same class (e.g., ondansetron after recent ondansetron) is inferior to class switching. Adjuncts include minimizing opioids, ensuring euvolemia, and considering isopropyl alcohol aromatherapy for short-term relief while definitive rescue takes effect.
educationalObjective: Treat PONV in PACU with agents from a different class than prophylaxis and consider haloperidol in refractory cases.

questionText: A 62-year-old man with obesity (BMI 38) and known OSA (uses home CPAP) undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia with an endotracheal tube. He was extubated in the OR after full neuromuscular reversal and followed simple commands. Ten minutes after PACU arrival, he becomes somnolent and snores loudly with paradoxical abdominal breathing. Vitals: BP 138/82 mm Hg, HR 92 bpm, RR 8/min with shallow breaths, SpO2 88% on 6 L/min simple face mask. The PACU nurse briefly improves the snoring with head extension, but obstruction recurs as soon as support is released. There are no visible secretions or blood. Which is the most appropriate next step to relieve this upper airway obstruction?

answers.text: Perform a two-handed jaw thrust and insert an oropharyngeal airway
answers.explanation: This directly relieves tongue-base/oropharyngeal collapse and splints the airway in a deeply sedated patient. It is the next escalation after simple head repositioning, with CPAP reserved if obstruction persists.

answers.text: Increase supplemental O2 to 15 L/min via nonrebreather mask
answers.explanation: Raising FiO2 treats hypoxemia but does not address the mechanical obstruction; delay in relieving obstruction risks worsening hypercapnia and hypoventilation.

answers.text: Administer naloxone 0.4 mg IV
answers.explanation: Opioid reversal may be needed if hypoventilation persists, but the priority is to relieve mechanical obstruction first. Additionally, 0.4 mg is an excessive initial dose and risks severe pain and sympathetic surge; titrate in 0.04 mg increments if used.

answers.text: Apply CPAP at 10 cm H2O via tight-fitting mask
answers.explanation: CPAP is appropriate if obstruction continues after airway maneuvers and adjuncts, especially in OSA. Applying CPAP to a still-collapsed airway may be ineffective and can cause gastric insufflation if the airway isn’t first opened.

answers.text: Proceed to endotracheal intubation
answers.explanation: Reintubation is premature when obstruction is likely due to soft-tissue collapse and should follow failure of basic maneuvers, airway adjuncts, and noninvasive support.

didactic: Upper airway obstruction in the PACU commonly results from tongue-base and soft-tissue collapse in sedated patients, especially with OSA and obesity, and presents with snoring, paradoxical breathing, and desaturation. Management is stepwise: first optimize positioning (sniffing, head tilt–chin lift) and apply a firm jaw thrust while delivering supplemental O2. If obstruction recurs or persists, insert an airway adjunct—use an oropharyngeal airway for deeply sedated/unconscious patients and a nasopharyngeal airway if gag reflex is present or OPA is not tolerated. If still obstructed, escalate to noninvasive support with CPAP (about 5–10 cm H2O) via a tight-fitting mask, which can splint the pharynx open; combine with jaw support as needed. Consider bag-mask ventilation and titrated opioid reversal (e.g., naloxone 0.04–0.08 mg IV increments) only after establishing airway patency. Reintubate if oxygenation/ventilation cannot be maintained despite these measures. Recognize laryngospasm as a separate cause (inspiratory stridor/silence) and treat with jaw thrust with CPAP; if refractory, give a small dose of propofol or succinylcholine.
