educationalObjective: Treat upper airway obstruction in PACU with repositioning, jaw thrust, oral/nasal airway, and escalate to CPAP if needed.

questionText: A 34-year-old nonsmoking woman with a history of severe motion sickness and prior postoperative vomiting presents for elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy under volatile-based general anesthesia. The case is expected to last 90 minutes with planned postoperative opioids. Preoperative ECG shows QTc 430 ms, and she has no diabetes. You aim to minimize PONV in this high-risk patient (Apfel 4/4). Which prophylactic regimen is MOST appropriate?

answers.text: After induction, give dexamethasone 8 mg IV; within 30 minutes of closure, give droperidol 0.625 mg IV and ondansetron 4 mg IV.
answers.explanation: Correct. This combines three different classes (glucocorticoid, dopamine antagonist, 5-HT3 antagonist) with evidence-based timing: dexamethasone at induction and ondansetron/droperidol near the end of surgery. This multimodal approach provides additive efficacy for high-risk patients without duplicating mechanisms.

answers.text: At induction, give ondansetron 4 mg IV and apply a scopolamine patch; withhold dexamethasone to avoid transient hyperglycemia.
answers.explanation: Incorrect. Ondansetron is more effective when administered near the end of surgery, and scopolamine requires several hours to become effective if applied perioperatively. Omitting dexamethasone in a non-diabetic high-risk patient sacrifices proven benefit.

answers.text: At induction, give droperidol 1.25 mg IV alone; treat any postoperative nausea in the PACU with ondansetron as needed.
answers.explanation: Incorrect. Single-agent prophylaxis is inadequate for Apfel 3–4 risk. Droperidol is best used as part of a multimodal regimen; relying on rescue rather than prevention increases PONV incidence.

answers.text: At induction, give palonosetron 0.075 mg IV and dexamethasone 8 mg IV; repeat ondansetron 4 mg IV at closure.
answers.explanation: Incorrect. This duplicates the 5-HT3 class without proven synergy; adding a different class (e.g., droperidol) provides greater incremental benefit in high-risk patients. Palonosetron’s long half-life also makes subsequent ondansetron redundant.

didactic: High-risk PONV (e.g., Apfel score 3–4: female sex, non-smoker, history of PONV/motion sickness, postoperative opioids) warrants multimodal prophylaxis using different drug classes. Recommended combinations include a 5-HT3 antagonist (e.g., ondansetron 4 mg IV), dexamethasone (4–8 mg IV), and a dopamine antagonist (e.g., droperidol 0.625–1.25 mg IV). Optimal timing enhances efficacy: give dexamethasone after induction, and administer ondansetron and droperidol within the last 30 minutes of the case. Avoid duplicating 5-HT3 antagonists, as this provides little added benefit compared with adding another mechanistic class. Low-dose droperidol is effective; consider QT risk but it is generally safe at 0.625–1.25 mg IV in patients with normal QTc. Scopolamine patches are effective when placed preoperatively (ideally ≥2–4 hours before) and are less reliable if applied intraoperatively. For rescue, choose an agent from a different class than those used for prophylaxis.
educationalObjective: Administer multimodal prophylaxis by combining drug classes (5-HT3 antagonist, dexamethasone, droperidol) in moderate–high risk.

questionText: A 5-year-old (20 kg) is scheduled for adenotonsillectomy for obstructive sleep apnea. The case is expected to last 45 minutes under sevoflurane with endotracheal intubation; the plan is to minimize opioids (acetaminophen and surgeon’s local infiltration). He had severe vomiting after a prior anesthetic. To reduce postoperative nausea and vomiting risk in this high-risk pediatric procedure, which prophylactic regimen is most appropriate?

answers.text: Dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg IV after induction plus ondansetron 0.1 mg/kg IV given ~15–30 minutes before emergence
answers.explanation: Multimodal prophylaxis with a steroid and a 5-HT3 antagonist is recommended for high-risk pediatric cases (e.g., tonsillectomy), with dexamethasone early (slower onset) and ondansetron near the end (shorter half-life). This timing and dosing optimize antiemetic effect while minimizing side effects.

answers.text: Ondansetron 0.1 mg/kg IV after induction; avoid dexamethasone due to bleeding risk
answers.explanation: Avoiding dexamethasone reflects an overestimation of bleeding risk; standard doses do not meaningfully increase postoperative hemorrhage in tonsillectomy. Early ondansetron is suboptimally timed and may wear off by emergence.

answers.text: Metoclopramide 0.1 mg/kg IV after induction plus dimenhydrinate 1 mg/kg IV at the end of the case
answers.explanation: While sometimes used, this combination is less effective than 5-HT3 antagonist plus steroid for pediatric tonsillectomy and carries more sedation/anticholinergic effects. It is not first-line in high-risk pediatric PONV.

answers.text: Dexamethasone 0.5 mg/kg IV at the end of surgery plus ondansetron 0.1 mg/kg IV at induction
answers.explanation: Both agents are mistimed: dexamethasone should be given early for delayed onset benefit, and ondansetron works best close to emergence. A higher dexamethasone dose may increase side effects without superior antiemesis.

answers.text: Transdermal scopolamine patch preoperatively plus ondansetron 0.1 mg/kg IV at the end of the case
answers.explanation: Scopolamine has limited evidence and unfavorable side effects in young children and requires hours for onset. It is not a preferred prophylactic agent in pediatric tonsillectomy.

didactic: Pediatric strabismus repair and adenotonsillectomy carry among the highest PONV risks in children, often warranting multimodal prophylaxis. The most evidence-supported regimen is a 5-HT3 antagonist (ondansetron $0.1\ \text{mg/kg}$, max 4 mg) administered within 30 minutes of emergence plus dexamethasone (commonly $0.15$–$0.5\ \text{mg/kg}$, max 8–10 mg) given at induction to account for its slower onset. Practical rule: give the steroid early and give the 5-HT3 late. Additional risk-reduction strategies include minimizing opioids, avoiding or limiting N2O, ensuring adequate hydration, and considering propofol-based TIVA, which lowers PONV compared with volatile anesthetics. In tonsillectomy, standard-dose dexamethasone reduces PONV and improves pain without a meaningful increase in postoperative hemorrhage risk. For rescue, choose an agent from a different class than those used prophylactically (e.g., droperidol $0.015\ \text{mg/kg}$ IV or low-dose metoclopramide).
educationalObjective: Apply special strategies in pediatrics (ondansetron + dexamethasone) and high-risk procedures (strabismus, tonsillectomy).

questionText: A 28-year-old nonsmoking woman undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy with general anesthesia. She receives dexamethasone 8 mg IV after induction and ondansetron 4 mg IV at skin closure. Thirty minutes after arrival to the PACU she reports severe nausea with one episode of emesis. Vitals are stable (BP 122/74 mm Hg, HR 88/min, SpO2 98% on room air) and her pre- and postoperative ECGs show normal QTc. Which of the following is the most appropriate rescue antiemetic now?

answers.text: Droperidol 0.625 mg IV
answers.explanation: Best rescue is a different pharmacologic class when prophylaxis fails within $6$ h. Low-dose droperidol (D2 antagonist) has rapid onset and strong efficacy for treatment of PONV after 5-HT3 antagonist prophylaxis.

answers.text: Ondansetron 4 mg IV (repeat dose)
answers.explanation: Incorrect because it repeats the same 5-HT3 mechanism used for prophylaxis and is less effective within $6$ h; it also adds QT risk without added benefit.

answers.text: Transdermal scopolamine patch
answers.explanation: Incorrect for immediate rescue; anticholinergic patches have delayed onset (several hours) and are more suitable for prophylaxis than acute treatment.

answers.text: Metoclopramide 10 mg IV
answers.explanation: Different class but less effective than butyrophenone dopamine antagonists for established PONV; reasonable if droperidol/haloperidol are contraindicated, but not the best option here.

answers.text: Aprepitant 40 mg PO
answers.explanation: An NK1 antagonist primarily for preoperative prophylaxis with slow onset; it is not useful for immediate rescue in the PACU.

didactic: If PONV occurs despite prophylaxis, rescue therapy should use an agent from a different class; repeating the same mechanism within about $6$ h (e.g., another 5-HT3 antagonist dose after ondansetron) is discouraged due to limited incremental efficacy and additive adverse effects (e.g., QT prolongation). Effective rescue options after 5-HT3 prophylaxis include dopamine antagonists such as droperidol 0.625–1.25 mg IV or haloperidol 0.5–1 mg IV, which have rapid onset and strong antiemetic efficacy. Metoclopramide 10 mg IV offers modest benefit and is reasonable if other dopamine antagonists are contraindicated. Anticholinergic scopolamine patches and NK1 antagonists (e.g., aprepitant) are mainly prophylactic; scopolamine has a delayed onset (hours), and aprepitant works best when given preoperatively. Always consider patient-specific contraindications: avoid QT-prolonging agents in patients with significant QTc prolongation or torsades risk, and avoid dopamine antagonists in Parkinson disease. Practical rule: prophylaxis fails early → switch class for rescue; late ($>6$ h) PONV may be treated with a repeat 5-HT3 antagonist dose if previously effective.
educationalObjective: Choose a rescue antiemetic from a different class when prophylaxis fails and avoid repeating the same mechanism.

questionText: A 29-year-old woman (BMI 24 kg/m^2), nonsmoker, with a history of severe motion sickness presents for outpatient laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. She is expected to require postoperative opioids for analgesia. Vitals are normal. Using the simplified Apfel PONV risk score, which prophylaxis strategy is most appropriate for this patient?

answers.text: Ondansetron 4 mg IV near the end of the case only
answers.explanation: With an Apfel score of 4 (female, nonsmoker, prior motion sickness/PONV, expected postoperative opioids) the predicted PONV risk is ~80%; single-agent prophylaxis is inadequate for very high risk.

answers.text: Dexamethasone 8 mg IV after induction only
answers.explanation: Dexamethasone is effective but monotherapy is insufficient in a patient with an Apfel score of 4; guidelines favor multimodal prophylaxis with at least two different classes.

answers.text: Dexamethasone 8 mg IV after induction plus ondansetron 4 mg IV near the end of the case
answers.explanation: An Apfel score of 4 (~80% risk) warrants multimodal prophylaxis. Combining agents from different classes and timing them appropriately (dexamethasone at induction, 5-HT3 antagonist at case end) provides superior protection.

answers.text: Transdermal scopolamine patch alone placed preoperatively
answers.explanation: Scopolamine is useful, especially for motion sickness and PONV, but as monotherapy it is inadequate at very high risk; it is better used as part of a multimodal regimen.

answers.text: Droperidol 0.625 mg IV near the end of the case only
answers.explanation: Low-dose droperidol is effective, but monotherapy is not sufficient for an Apfel score of 4; at least two agents from different classes are recommended.

didactic: The simplified Apfel score assigns 1 point each for female sex, nonsmoking status, prior PONV or motion sickness, and planned postoperative opioids; risk increases roughly linearly: 0→~10%, 1→~20%, 2→~40%, 3→~60%, 4→~80%. Patients with scores ≥3 warrant multimodal prophylaxis using at least two antiemetics from different classes, timed for peak effect (e.g., dexamethasone 4–8 mg IV at induction plus ondansetron 4 mg IV at the end). Additional risk-reduction strategies include avoiding emetogenic anesthetics (minimize volatile agents, avoid $\mathrm{N_2O}$), using propofol TIVA, and reducing postoperative opioids with multimodal analgesia. If prophylaxis fails, rescue therapy should come from a different class than those already given. Typical effective doses: ondansetron 4 mg IV, dexamethasone 4–8 mg IV, droperidol 0.625–1.25 mg IV, and transdermal scopolamine 1.5 mg applied preoperatively. Stratifying prophylaxis intensity to the Apfel score prevents overtreatment of low-risk patients and undertreatment of high-risk patients.
educationalObjective: Identify PONV risk using simplified scores (e.g., Apfel) and stratify prophylaxis intensity.

questionText: A 28-year-old nonsmoking woman undergoes outpatient laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. She received dexamethasone 8 mg at induction and ondansetron 4 mg at closure. In the PACU 20 minutes later she reports moderate nausea without vomiting. Vitals: BP 122/70 mm Hg, HR 78 bpm, RR 14, SpO2 98% on 2 L/min O2 via nasal cannula. She declines additional sedating medications and wants to be discharged promptly. Which intervention is the most appropriate low-risk adjunct to provide rapid symptom relief?

answers.text: Have the patient take several deep inhalations of isopropyl alcohol vapor from an alcohol pad held beneath the nares.
answers.explanation: Isopropyl alcohol inhalation provides rapid, short-term reduction in nausea intensity in the PACU with minimal risk and no sedation, making it an ideal nonpharmacologic adjunct alongside antiemetics.

answers.text: Apply an elastic acupressure band over the P6 (Neiguan) point on the volar wrist.
answers.explanation: P6 acupressure is low-risk and can reduce PONV, but its onset as a rescue measure is less immediate and effect less consistent than isopropyl alcohol inhalation for rapid PACU relief; it is often used prophylactically or as an adjunct started earlier.

answers.text: Place a transdermal scopolamine patch behind the ear.
answers.explanation: Scopolamine is pharmacologic and has a delayed onset (typically 2–4 hours) with anticholinergic side effects; it is unsuitable for rapid relief in the immediate PACU setting.

answers.text: Offer peppermint-flavored chewing gum to stimulate gastric motility.
answers.explanation: Chewing gum is not an established treatment for PONV and may pose aspiration risk in the PACU; its primary evidence relates to postoperative ileus rather than acute nausea.

answers.text: Increase supplemental oxygen to FiO2 = 1.0 via face mask.
answers.explanation: High inspired O2 has not reliably reduced PONV and is unlikely to help a normoxic patient (SpO2 98%); the misconception is that oxygen itself treats nausea absent hypoxemia.

didactic: Nonpharmacologic strategies are useful low-risk complements to antiemetics for PONV. Isopropyl alcohol aromatherapy (sniffing an alcohol pad for a few deep breaths, repeated as needed) provides rapid, short-term relief of nausea intensity in the PACU without sedation or interactions, making it ideal for immediate rescue. P6 (Neiguan) acupressure—located 2–3 fingerbreadths proximal to the distal wrist crease between the palmaris longus and flexor carpi radialis tendons—reduces PONV and can be used as an adjunct, but its rescue effect is less immediate than alcohol inhalation; applying bands preoperatively or early postoperatively may enhance benefit. Peppermint oil aromatherapy is another low-risk option with mixed but generally favorable evidence for nausea relief; it can be considered when available. Transdermal scopolamine is best placed preoperatively for prophylaxis due to a 2–4 hour onset and anticholinergic side effects. In normoxic patients, increasing FiO2 does not reliably treat nausea. Practical approach: for acute PACU nausea after standard antiemetics, start with isopropyl alcohol inhalation and consider adding P6 acupressure while arranging further pharmacologic rescue from a different class if needed.
educationalObjective: Integrate nonpharmacologic adjuncts (acupressure P6, aromatherapy) as low-risk complements to drugs.

questionText:
A 32-year-old nonsmoking woman with a history of severe motion sickness undergoes ambulatory laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. She received multimodal PONV prophylaxis: aprepitant 80 mg PO 2 hours preop, dexamethasone 8 mg IV after induction, palonosetron 0.075 mg IV at closure, and a transdermal scopolamine patch placed preoperatively. In PACU she is comfortable and will be discharged with a short course of oxycodone PRN. You want to minimize post-discharge nausea and vomiting (PDNV) and provide effective rescue therapy.

Which discharge prescription and instructions are MOST appropriate?

answers.text: Metoclopramide 10 mg PO every 6–8 hours as needed for nausea, avoid driving if sedated or restless, keep the scopolamine patch on for 72 hours (remove earlier if blurry vision/urinary retention), and call/return if unable to keep fluids or if two doses fail.
answers.explanation: Best choice: use a different receptor class for rescue (dopamine antagonist) given long-acting 5-HT3 (palonosetron), NK1 (aprepitant), steroid, and anticholinergic already on board. Instructions align with patch duration and emphasize safety/escalation.

answers.text: Ondansetron 4 mg PO every 6 hours as needed for nausea, remove the scopolamine patch after 24 hours.
answers.explanation: Misconception: “more 5-HT3 is better.” Palonosetron has a long $t_{1/2}\approx40$ h and sustained receptor binding, so additional 5-HT3 offers limited early benefit; removing scopolamine at 24 h prematurely reduces protection (patch lasts ~72 h).

answers.text: Replace the transdermal scopolamine patch daily for 3 days and avoid any other antiemetics.
answers.explanation: Misconception: maximizing anticholinergic therapy. The patch delivers drug over ~72 h and is not replaced daily; relying solely on anticholinergic therapy neglects effective rescue from a different class and increases anticholinergic adverse effects.

answers.text: No outpatient antiemetic is needed because palonosetron covers nausea for 72 hours.
answers.explanation: Misconception: long-acting prophylaxis obviates rescue. High PDNV-risk patients still benefit from an at-home rescue plan; breakthrough symptoms can occur despite prophylaxis.

answers.text: Promethazine 25 mg PO every 4 hours around the clock for 48 hours, caution about drowsiness.
answers.explanation: Misconception: scheduled sedating antihistamines are superior. Routine around-the-clock dosing increases sedation and respiratory depression risk with opioids; rescue should be PRN and from a different class with clear escalation triggers.

didactic: High PDNV-risk patients (e.g., female, age <50, opioid use, PACU nausea) benefit from long-acting prophylaxis plus a home rescue plan. Key durations: palonosetron $t_{1/2}\approx40$ h with efficacy up to ~72 h; transdermal scopolamine releases drug for ~72 h; aprepitant provides sustained NK1 blockade over ~24 h. Rescue therapy should use a different class than prophylaxis—if 5-HT3 was used (especially palonosetron), choose a dopamine antagonist (e.g., metoclopramide 10 mg PO q6–8 h PRN or prochlorperazine 10 mg PO q6–8 h PRN) rather than another 5-HT3 early after surgery. Provide clear instructions: leave the scopolamine patch on for 72 h (remove earlier if blurry vision, confusion, or urinary retention), avoid driving if sedated or with akathisia, and seek care if unable to keep liquids or if symptoms persist after 1–2 rescue doses. Rule of thumb: if prophylaxis fails within ~6 h, switch classes; if >6 h and a short-acting 5-HT3 was used, repeating a 5-HT3 may be reasonable—palonosetron is an exception due to its long receptor occupancy.
educationalObjective: Plan for PDNV after ambulatory surgery with long-acting prophylaxis and clear rescue instructions.

questionText: A 46-year-old woman with congenital long QT syndrome (on nadolol) undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. She received dexamethasone 8 mg IV at induction and ondansetron 4 mg IV at skin closure. In the PACU 20 minutes later she has severe nausea. Vitals: BP 128/72 mm Hg, HR 55/min (sinus), SpO2 99% on 2 L/min O2. An ECG shows $QT_c = 540\,$ms (baseline preop $QT_c = 500\,$ms). Labs just resulted: $K^+ = 3.2\,\text{mEq/L}$, $Mg^{2+} = 1.6\,\text{mg/dL}$. Which medication is the most appropriate immediate treatment for her nausea?

answers.text: Propofol 20 mg IV bolus
answers.explanation: Propofol has rapid-onset antiemetic effects at subhypnotic doses and does not meaningfully prolong $QT_c$; it is preferred for rescue in patients with marked $QT_c$ prolongation and recent exposure to other QT-prolonging antiemetics. Electrolyte repletion (target $K^+ > 4.0\,\text{mEq/L}$, $Mg^{2+} > 2.0\,\text{mg/dL}$) should also be performed, but propofol is the safest immediate antiemetic choice here.

answers.text: Haloperidol 1 mg IV
answers.explanation: Haloperidol prolongs $QT_c$ and increases torsades de pointes risk, especially in patients with baseline $QT_c > 500$ ms, bradycardia, hypokalemia, or concurrent QT-prolonging agents (e.g., ondansetron). Using it now compounds multiple risk factors.

answers.text: Metoclopramide 10 mg IV
answers.explanation: Metoclopramide (a dopamine antagonist) can prolong $QT_c$ and has dose-dependent risk of arrhythmia and extrapyramidal effects. In a patient with $QT_c = 540$ ms and low $K^+$/$Mg^{2+}$, this adds avoidable proarrhythmic risk.

answers.text: Promethazine 12.5 mg IV
answers.explanation: Phenothiazines (e.g., promethazine, prochlorperazine) can prolong $QT_c$ and cause hypotension; they are not preferred in marked $QT_c$ prolongation, especially after another QT-prolonging antiemetic has been given.

answers.text: Ondansetron 4 mg IV (repeat dose)
answers.explanation: 5-HT3 antagonists variably prolong $QT_c$ (ondansetron most notably). Re-dosing in a patient with $QT_c = 540$ ms, bradycardia, and hypokalemia increases torsades risk and offers limited additional efficacy so soon after the initial dose.

didactic: Marked $QT_c$ prolongation (e.g., $QT_c > 500$ ms) substantially increases torsades de pointes risk, which is further amplified by bradycardia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and stacking multiple QT-prolonging drugs. Among antiemetics, 5-HT3 antagonists (especially ondansetron), dopamine antagonists (droperidol, haloperidol, metoclopramide), and phenothiazines (promethazine, prochlorperazine) can prolong $QT_c$; avoid combining them in susceptible patients. Safer choices include propofol for rescue (10–20 mg IV boluses), dexamethasone, scopolamine, and NK1 antagonists (e.g., aprepitant), with palonosetron having minimal QT effect if a 5-HT3 agent is needed for prophylaxis. For patients at risk, correct electrolytes to $K^+ > 4.0\,\text{mEq/L}$ and $Mg^{2+} > 2.0\,\text{mg/dL}$, maintain normothermia and normocapnia, and avoid bradycardia. If torsades occurs, give magnesium sulfate 2 g IV and treat per ACLS, with overdrive pacing or isoproterenol when indicated. A practical rule: in the PACU with prolonged $QT_c$, choose propofol for immediate rescue and reserve QT-neutral/prophylactic agents for subsequent prevention.
educationalObjective: Recognize and manage QT prolongation risk when combining antiemetics or in susceptible patients.

questionText: A 29-year-old ASA II woman (nonsmoker) with prior severe postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) and motion sickness presents for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. After 45 minutes, she is anesthetized with sevoflurane (≈1.1 MAC) in 50% N2O/50% O2 at 2 L/min; she has received fentanyl 100 mcg and 300 mL lactated Ringer’s. The surgeon anticipates another 60 minutes for cholangiography. Due to a formulary shortage, you have already given the only antiemetic available and cannot add others. To reduce her baseline PONV risk independent of additional antiemetic drugs, which intraoperative change is MOST effective?

answers.text: Convert to propofol-based TIVA (e.g., propofol 100–150 mcg/kg/min) with air/O2 and discontinue both sevoflurane and N2O
answers.explanation: Propofol TIVA removes the emetogenic stimulus of volatile agents and eliminates N2O, producing one of the largest single modifiable reductions in baseline PONV risk—particularly in high-risk, laparoscopic cases.

answers.text: Maintain volatile anesthesia but avoid further opioids by substituting multimodal analgesia (e.g., ketamine 0.3 mg/kg and IV lidocaine infusion)
answers.explanation: Opioid-sparing strategies lower PONV risk, but the continued presence of volatile anesthetic and N2O leaves major emetogenic drivers in place. The magnitude of risk reduction is smaller than with switching to propofol TIVA.

answers.text: Administer a 1 L bolus of lactated Ringer’s to correct fasting deficit and promote euvolemia
answers.explanation: Adequate hydration modestly reduces PONV, especially for laparoscopic intra-abdominal procedures, but its effect is less than eliminating volatile/N2O with TIVA.

answers.text: Increase N2O to 70% to reduce sevoflurane requirement (lower MAC)
answers.explanation: N2O is independently emetogenic; increasing its fraction typically increases PONV risk despite lowering volatile MAC.

answers.text: Place a transdermal scopolamine patch now
answers.explanation: This adds pharmacologic prophylaxis rather than reducing baseline risk and has delayed onset (hours), offering little immediate benefit in an ongoing case; the prompt also restricts adding antiemetics.

didactic: Baseline PONV risk can be lowered by modifying the anesthetic technique and perioperative physiology before adding antiemetic drugs. Volatile anesthetics and N2O are emetogenic; switching to propofol TIVA removes these triggers and provides a risk reduction comparable to or greater than a single antiemetic, with additive benefit when combined with prophylaxis. Avoiding N2O is particularly helpful in long or laparoscopic procedures. Opioid-sparing multimodal analgesia (acetaminophen, NSAIDs, low-dose ketamine 0.2–0.5 mg/kg, IV lidocaine, regional blocks) reduces postoperative opioid exposure, further lowering PONV risk. Adequate hydration (e.g., targeting euvolemia with balanced crystalloids) provides a modest additional reduction. Practical approach in high-risk patients (e.g., high Apfel score): use propofol TIVA when feasible, avoid N2O, minimize opioids with multimodal analgesia, and ensure hydration; then layer pharmacologic prophylaxis as available.
educationalObjective: Reduce baseline risk with TIVA, opioid-sparing analgesia, hydration, and avoidance of nitrous when feasible.

questionText: A 35-year-old woman (nonsmoker) with a history of severe postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) presents for a 2-hour laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. You plan to use volatile anesthesia and perioperative opioids. Immediately after induction, your nurse asks when to administer dexamethasone and ondansetron for optimal PONV prophylaxis. To maximize efficacy in the PACU, which timing strategy is best?

answers.text: Administer dexamethasone 8 mg IV and ondansetron 4 mg IV together at induction
answers.explanation: Giving ondansetron at induction is too early; with a $t_{1/2}$ of ~3–4 h and onset within minutes, its effect may wane by early PACU for a 2-hour case. This reflects the misconception that all antiemetics should be front-loaded at induction.

answers.text: Administer dexamethasone 8 mg IV at induction and ondansetron 4 mg IV 15–30 minutes before emergence
answers.explanation: Dexamethasone has a delayed onset (approximately 1–2 h), so induction dosing aligns peak effect with the early postoperative period. Ondansetron has a rapid onset and shorter duration; dosing near case end best covers the immediate PACU window when emetogenic stimuli peak.

answers.text: Administer both dexamethasone 8 mg IV and ondansetron 4 mg IV at the end of surgery
answers.explanation: Dosing dexamethasone at the end misses its delayed onset and offers minimal benefit in early PACU. This stems from the misconception that all agents should be given when the patient is most symptomatic rather than timed to pharmacodynamics.

answers.text: Administer ondansetron 4 mg IV at induction and dexamethasone 8 mg IV at the end of surgery
answers.explanation: This reverses optimal timing: early ondansetron may wear off by PACU, while late dexamethasone has not yet taken effect. The error is misunderstanding that glucocorticoids require early administration, whereas 5-HT3 antagonists are most effective when given near emergence.

answers.text: Administer dexamethasone 8 mg IV at induction and repeat ondansetron 4 mg IV every 30 minutes intraoperatively
answers.explanation: Repeated ondansetron dosing intraoperatively is not evidence-based, increases QTc risk, and offers no added efficacy. The misconception is that more frequent dosing improves prophylaxis rather than proper timing.

didactic: Antiemetic timing should match pharmacodynamics and the emetogenic timeline. Dexamethasone has a delayed onset (~1–2 h) with long duration (~24 h), so give it at induction to align effect with the early postoperative period. 5-HT3 antagonists (e.g., ondansetron) have rapid onset (minutes), peak within 30–60 minutes, and a $t_{1/2}$ of ~3–4 h; administer 15–30 minutes before emergence to cover the PACU when gut serotonin release and vagal activation are highest. Practical rule: steroid early, 5-HT3 late. Scopolamine transdermal requires preoperative placement (≥2–4 h), and droperidol or haloperidol are typically given near case end; neurokinin-1 antagonists (e.g., aprepitant) are given preop (1–3 h). For high-risk patients, combine classes with proper timing and minimize emetogenic triggers (volatile agents, nitrous oxide, opioids) when feasible.
educationalObjective: Time antiemetics correctly (e.g., dexamethasone at induction; ondansetron near case end) to maximize efficacy.

questionText:
A 36-year-old woman with a history of severe motion sickness and prior postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is scheduled for outpatient laparoscopic cholecystectomy at 07:30. She will be discharged the same day and faces a 90-minute, winding car ride home. Anesthesia will be TIVA with propofol and fentanyl; dexamethasone will be given after induction and ondansetron at closure. She asks about using a scopolamine patch to help with the ride home. She has no glaucoma, urinary retention, or cognitive impairment.

Which of the following is the most appropriate use of transdermal scopolamine for this patient?

answers.text: Instruct her to apply a transdermal scopolamine patch the evening before surgery (or ≥4 hours preop) and keep it on for up to 72 hours, with counseling about dry mouth, blurred vision/mydriasis from ocular contamination, urinary retention, and confusion in susceptible patients.
answers.explanation: Transdermal scopolamine has an onset of 2–4 hours (peak ~6 hours) and provides sustained antiemetic effect for motion-related nausea; proper timing and counseling about anticholinergic side effects are essential.

answers.text: Apply the patch in pre-op holding 30 minutes before induction to provide immediate protection during the car ride home.
answers.explanation: Onset is not immediate; applying ≤1 hour before surgery provides little early benefit for the ride home and underestimates the delayed onset (2–4 hours).

answers.text: Place the patch in the PACU and instruct her to remove it after 6 hours to minimize urinary retention risk.
answers.explanation: PACU placement is too late for the car ride, and routine early removal is unnecessary; urinary retention is possible but managed by patient selection and counseling, not arbitrary early removal.

answers.text: Avoid scopolamine because concomitant TIVA markedly increases the risk of oversedation and respiratory depression.
answers.explanation: Scopolamine may cause mild sedation or confusion, but it does not meaningfully potentiate respiratory depression with TIVA; its main risks are anticholinergic effects and CNS delirium in susceptible patients.

answers.text: Place a scopolamine patch the morning of surgery but cut it in half to reduce side effects while preserving antiemetic efficacy.
answers.explanation: Do not cut transdermal patches; it disrupts drug delivery and does not solve the timing problem. The patch still requires several hours for effect even at a reduced dose.

didactic: Transdermal scopolamine is a central M1-antagonist particularly effective for vestibular (motion-related) nausea and for reducing late PONV in ambulatory patients. The standard 1.5 mg patch delivers approximately 1 mg over 72 hours and has an onset of 2–4 hours with peak effect around 6 hours; therefore, it should be applied the evening before or at least several hours preoperatively if early protection is desired. It complements 5-HT3 antagonists and dexamethasone by targeting a different pathway and is poor for rescue of established nausea due to its slow onset. Anticholinergic adverse effects include dry mouth, blurred vision/mydriasis (often from hand-to-eye transfer), tachycardia, urinary retention, and confusion or delirium—use caution in older adults, patients with narrow-angle glaucoma, and those with significant prostatic hypertrophy. Counsel patients to wash hands after handling the patch and to remove it if troublesome side effects occur; unilateral mydriasis after accidental ocular exposure is benign and resolves with time. Practical rule: for motion-sensitive, high-risk outpatients, apply the patch ≥4 hours preop and leave in place up to 72 hours to cover the car ride home and the vulnerable first postoperative day.
educationalObjective: Use transdermal scopolamine for motion-related nausea with attention to timing and anticholinergic side effects.

questionText:
A 56-year-old man (BMI 35) with small-bowel obstruction and frequent emesis is brought for emergent laparotomy. After thorough preoxygenation ($\mathrm{FiO_2}=1.0$), you perform RSI with propofol and succinylcholine. Cricoid pressure has been applied by a trained assistant since loss of consciousness. On the first laryngoscopy attempt, you obtain a Cormack–Lehane grade 3 view; external laryngeal manipulation does not help. SpO$_2$ falls from 100% to 86% over 45 seconds. You pause to ventilate but note poor chest rise, high mask pressures, and minimal capnography while cricoid pressure is maintained. The stomach is not distended, and there is no visible regurgitation in the oropharynx.

Which immediate action is the most appropriate to restore oxygenation while minimizing overall harm?

answers.text: Release cricoid pressure completely and initiate gentle bag-mask ventilation with PEEP using 100% O2
answers.explanation: When cricoid pressure impedes ventilation or intubation with desaturation, it should be released to prioritize oxygenation; aspiration risk is outweighed by the imminent risk of hypoxemia. Releasing CP facilitates bag-mask ventilation and is supported by airway guidelines.

answers.text: Increase cricoid pressure to 40 N and attempt another laryngoscopy without ventilating
answers.explanation: Increasing force commonly worsens the glottic view and further impedes ventilation; it does not reliably occlude the esophagus due to lateral displacement. Persisting with intubation during desaturation violates the oxygenation-first principle.

answers.text: Maintain cricoid pressure and insert a supraglottic airway to oxygenate
answers.explanation: Cricoid pressure frequently obstructs insertion and seating of supraglottic devices and reduces seal pressure. If an SGA is chosen, CP should be eased or released to allow placement and ventilation.

answers.text: Maintain cricoid pressure and attempt a bougie-assisted intubation as the next step
answers.explanation: Bougie use may help a poor view, but oxygenation takes priority when SpO$_2$ is falling and mask ventilation is ineffective. Continuing intubation attempts under CP in a desaturating patient increases hypoxemia risk.

answers.text: Convert the assistant’s cricoid pressure to firm external laryngeal manipulation while keeping the airway closed to ventilation
answers.explanation: External laryngeal manipulation (bimanual) can improve the view, but it does not address the current failure to ventilate. With worsening hypoxemia, restoring ventilation by easing or releasing CP is indicated first.

didactic: Cricoid pressure aims to compress the esophagus against the vertebral body to reduce passive regurgitation, typically at ~10 N while awake and ~30 N after loss of consciousness. Its efficacy is inconsistent: the esophagus may be lateral to the cricoid, and CP can worsen the laryngoscopic view, impede bag-mask ventilation, and hinder supraglottic airway or gastric tube insertion. Airway safety prioritizes oxygenation; if CP interferes with laryngoscopy or ventilation, it should be adjusted (lightened, repositioned) and, if needed, released—especially in a cannot-intubate/cannot-ventilate or desaturation scenario. Maintain CP only until the endotracheal cuff is inflated and placement is confirmed by sustained ETCO$_2$; do not let CP delay lifesaving ventilation. If active vomiting or forceful retching occurs, release CP to avoid esophageal rupture while suctioning and positioning (e.g., head-down). Practical rule: lighten CP first to assess improvement; if ineffective and oxygenation is threatened, release completely to restore ventilation.
educationalObjective: Apply and manage cricoid pressure correctly, including when to ease or release it to improve laryngoscopy or ventilation.

questionText: A 62-year-old man with a high-grade small-bowel obstruction presents for urgent laparotomy. He has had multiple episodes of bilious emesis and abdominal distension. An NG tube placed in the ED has drained 1.2 L and is currently clamped for transport. In the OR he is hemodynamically stable, alert, and supine. You plan a rapid-sequence induction with a cuffed ETT. Which of the following is the best next step to reduce aspiration risk before induction?

answers.text: Remove the NG tube to avoid interference with laryngoscopy and proceed with standard supine RSI
answers.explanation: Removing the NG tube eliminates the ability to decompress the stomach immediately prior to induction, increasing residual volume and aspiration risk; supine positioning also increases intragastric pressure.

answers.text: Place the patient $20^\circ$ head-up and actively suction the NG tube immediately before RSI
answers.explanation: Head-up positioning reduces regurgitation by lowering intragastric pressure and increasing barrier pressure, and immediate NG suction decreases gastric volume—both key in small-bowel obstruction.

answers.text: Keep the patient supine and apply cricoid pressure during preoxygenation to prevent regurgitation
answers.explanation: Cricoid pressure does not reduce gastric volume and may worsen mask ventilation or glottic view; supine positioning increases aspiration risk compared with head-up.

answers.text: Provide several large-tidal-volume mask breaths to deepen anesthesia prior to intubation
answers.explanation: Positive-pressure mask ventilation with high inspiratory pressures increases gastric insufflation and intragastric pressure, worsening aspiration risk.

answers.text: Administer IV ranitidine and metoclopramide 5 minutes pre-induction
answers.explanation: H2 blockers require ≥30–60 minutes to meaningfully reduce acid secretion, and metoclopramide is not useful (and may be harmful) in mechanical obstruction; neither addresses the immediate large gastric volume.

didactic: Aspiration risk is driven primarily by gastric volume and the gradient favoring regurgitation (barrier pressure). Barrier pressure can be conceptualized as $\text{LES pressure} - \text{intragastric pressure}$; positioning $20$–$30^\circ$ head-up lowers intragastric pressure and reduces passive regurgitation. In conditions with probable large residual gastric volume—bowel obstruction, active vomiting, or severe symptomatic gastroparesis—gastric decompression with NG/OG suction immediately before induction is indicated. During RSI, avoid or minimize mask ventilation; if absolutely necessary, keep inspiratory pressure $<12$–$15$ cm H2O to limit gastric insufflation. Pharmacologic measures are adjuncts: nonparticulate antacids (e.g., sodium citrate) raise pH rapidly, whereas H2 blockers/PPIs require time and metoclopramide is for gastroparesis, not mechanical obstruction. Cricoid pressure has mixed evidence and should not delay intubation or impair ventilation; prioritize head-up positioning, active decompression, prompt intubation, and cuff inflation.
educationalObjective: Assess and reduce aspiration risk in gastroparesis, bowel obstruction, or severe GERD, including gastric decompression when indicated.

questionText: A 35-year-old man (90 kg) presents for emergent laparotomy for peritonitis and small-bowel distention 10 days after a 20% TBSA flame burn to the trunk and thighs. He is awake, in moderate pain, and has received an NG tube but continues to belch gastric contents. Vitals: BP 132/78 mm Hg, HR 105/min, SpO2 99% on room air. Labs: K+ 4.6 mEq/L, Cr 0.9 mg/dL. You plan a true RSI (no mask ventilation) with video laryngoscopy; the cart stocks sugammadex. Airway exam is routine. Which neuromuscular blocker strategy is most appropriate to optimize RSI conditions while minimizing catastrophic complications in this patient?

answers.text: Administer succinylcholine 1.5 mg/kg for RSI
answers.explanation: Burns >24–48 hours upregulate extrajunctional ACh receptors; succinylcholine can cause dangerous hyperkalemia even with a normal baseline K+. Using succinylcholine here risks malignant arrhythmias.

answers.text: Administer rocuronium 1.2 mg/kg IV and have sugammadex 16 mg/kg immediately available for rescue
answers.explanation: High-dose rocuronium (1.0–1.2 mg/kg) provides intubating conditions in ~60 s and avoids succinylcholine-induced hyperkalemia in subacute burns; burn-related resistance favors the higher dose. Sugammadex 16 mg/kg can rapidly reverse profound block if a can’t intubate, can’t ventilate scenario occurs, and normal renal function supports its use.

answers.text: Administer rocuronium 0.6 mg/kg to shorten duration and reduce apnea time
answers.explanation: A 0.6 mg/kg dose has slower onset and inferior RSI conditions, increasing aspiration risk; burn patients are relatively resistant to nondepolarizers, further delaying onset. Shorter duration is not helpful if intubating conditions are inadequate.

answers.text: Give a defasciculating dose of rocuronium (0.03 mg/kg) followed by succinylcholine 1.0 mg/kg
answers.explanation: Precurarization does not prevent succinylcholine-induced hyperkalemia and can delay onset or worsen intubating conditions. Succinylcholine remains contraindicated after subacute burns.

answers.text: Administer vecuronium 0.1 mg/kg to avoid hyperkalemia
answers.explanation: Vecuronium has a slower onset than high-dose rocuronium and is suboptimal for RSI. It avoids hyperkalemia but sacrifices rapid, reliable intubating conditions needed in a full-stomach patient.

didactic: For RSI, succinylcholine (1.0–1.5 mg/kg) provides the fastest onset (~30–60 s) but is contraindicated in conditions that upregulate extrajunctional ACh receptors (e.g., burns after 24–48 h, denervation, stroke, prolonged immobilization, neuromuscular disease) due to risk of severe hyperkalemia. High-dose rocuronium (1.0–1.2 mg/kg) achieves similar intubating conditions at ~60 s but with longer duration (typically 45–70 min); burn-related resistance to nondepolarizers supports using the higher end of dosing. Sugammadex forms tight complexes with aminosteroid NMBs; 16 mg/kg can immediately reverse profound block shortly after 1.2 mg/kg rocuronium and is the recommended dose for CICV rescue. Avoid relying on sugammadex in severe renal failure because clearance of the rocuronium–sugammadex complex is impaired; otherwise, it is appropriate to have it drawn up for RSI rescue. Neostigmine cannot rapidly reverse deep blockade and is not suitable for immediate rescue. Practical rule: if succinylcholine is contraindicated, use rocuronium 1.2 mg/kg and plan for sugammadex 16 mg/kg rescue when renal function is adequate.
educationalObjective: Choose succinylcholine versus high-dose rocuronium for RSI and plan for sugammadex rescue when appropriate.

questionText: A 57-year-old man with a small-bowel obstruction (repeated vomiting), BMI 42, and obstructive sleep apnea presents for urgent laparotomy. He is preoxygenated in the ramped position to an end-tidal O2 of 90% and undergoes RSI with etomidate and succinylcholine while cricoid pressure is applied. Thirty-five seconds after loss of consciousness, SpO2 falls from 100% to 88%, and the video laryngoscope is not yet ready; you anticipate at least 30–45 more seconds before intubation can be attempted. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate step to prevent hypoxemia while minimizing aspiration risk?

answers.text: Begin two-person mask ventilation with 100% O2 using a tight jaw-thrust seal, limiting peak inspiratory pressure to $\le 12\ \text{cm H2O}$ (PEEP 0–5) with small tidal volumes.
answers.explanation: Gentle mask ventilation prevents critical hypoxemia in patients with low FRC while keeping peak pressure below the approximate esophageal opening pressure, thereby minimizing gastric insufflation and aspiration risk. A two-hand seal and jaw thrust allow effective ventilation at low pressures.

answers.text: Avoid any ventilation and proceed directly to laryngoscopy as soon as the equipment arrives, accepting transient desaturation.
answers.explanation: “No-ventilation” RSI increases the risk of severe hypoxemia in obese or hypoxemic patients who desaturate rapidly; in this context, the benefit of gentle low-pressure ventilation outweighs the small incremental aspiration risk.

answers.text: Provide rapid mask ventilation with high flows targeting a peak inspiratory pressure of $25\ \text{cm H2O}$ to quickly restore SpO2.
answers.explanation: High peak pressures ($\gtrsim 15$–$20\ \text{cm H2O}$) increase gastric insufflation and aspiration risk. Oxygenation should be restored using low-pressure breaths rather than forceful ventilation.

answers.text: Insert a laryngeal mask airway to re-oxygenate and then intubate through it once stabilized.
answers.explanation: An LMA is not preferred in a full-stomach RSI because it can increase aspiration risk and delays definitive airway control; mask ventilation at low pressures is faster and safer here.

answers.text: Maintain firm cricoid pressure and rely on apneic oxygenation via high-flow nasal cannula, avoiding any mask ventilation.
answers.explanation: Apneic oxygenation can prolong safe apnea but is not a rescue for rapidly falling SpO2; once desaturation is underway, active ventilation is needed. Cricoid pressure alone does not improve oxygenation.

didactic: Gentle mask ventilation during RSI is justified when the risk of rapid desaturation is high (obesity, pregnancy, pediatrics, preexisting hypoxemia) or when intubation is delayed. To minimize gastric insufflation, keep peak inspiratory pressure below the esophageal opening pressure (roughly $15$–$20\ \text{cm H2O}$); many adopt a conservative target of $\le 12$–$15\ \text{cm H2O}$. Use a two-person mask seal with jaw thrust, 100% O2, small tidal volumes (about $4$–$6\ \text{mL/kg}$ IBW), and a slow rate (6–8/min); if using PEEP, ensure $\text{Peak} = \text{PEEP} + \text{Driving pressure} \le 12$–$15\ \text{cm H2O}$. Head-up/ramped positioning increases FRC and improves preoxygenation; consider nasal apneic oxygenation as an adjunct but not as a rescue once SpO2 is falling. If cricoid pressure impedes ventilation or laryngoscopy, it should be adjusted or released. The key principle is that insufflation risk is pressure-driven, so prioritize low peak airway pressures while promptly restoring oxygenation.
educationalObjective: Decide when gentle mask ventilation during RSI is justified to prevent hypoxemia and how to limit insufflation.

questionText: A 58-year-old man presents for urgent laparotomy for small-bowel obstruction after 24 hours of bilious emesis and abdominal distension. He last ate 10 hours ago but has had persistent vomiting. Vitals: BP 148/82 mm Hg, HR 105/min, SpO2 97% on room air. Airway exam: Mallampati IV, inter-incisor distance 2 cm, thyromental distance ~5 cm, limited neck extension from ankylosing spondylitis, and a thick beard. The surgical team is ready and requests rapid induction. Which airway management strategy is MOST appropriate to minimize aspiration risk while maximizing patient safety?

answers.text: Awake flexible bronchoscopy–guided endotracheal intubation after topicalization and minimal sedation, followed by induction of anesthesia
answers.explanation: Severe aspiration risk (small-bowel obstruction, ongoing emesis) plus multiple predictors of a difficult airway (limited mouth opening, limited neck extension, beard) favors an awake intubation to maintain spontaneous ventilation and airway reflexes until the airway is secured. This approach minimizes the risk of a "can’t intubate, can’t oxygenate" scenario that would be more dangerous under paralysis.

answers.text: Standard rapid sequence induction with cricoid pressure, no mask ventilation, and succinylcholine
answers.explanation: RSI minimizes time with an unprotected airway in full-stomach patients, but it is unsafe here given strong predictors of both difficult laryngoscopy and difficult mask ventilation. Paralysis before securing the airway increases the risk of failed ventilation and hypoxemia; cricoid pressure can also worsen glottic view.

answers.text: Modified RSI with gentle mask ventilation and rocuronium to mitigate desaturation risk
answers.explanation: Modified RSI (gentle BMV ≤15 cm H2O) is useful when desaturation risk is high and the airway is expected to be straightforward. In this case, the major problem is a predicted difficult airway; adding paralysis still risks a failed airway while gastric insufflation may worsen aspiration risk in obstruction.

answers.text: Inhalational induction maintaining spontaneous ventilation, then intubation after deep anesthesia
answers.explanation: A prolonged inhalational induction in an adult with a full stomach increases time with an unprotected airway and risks regurgitation/aspiration. It also does not mitigate the anticipated difficult laryngoscopy and may lead to loss of airway reflexes without a secured airway.

answers.text: Supraglottic airway placement after IV induction as a bridge, then intubation through the device after gastric decompression
answers.explanation: Supraglottic airways do not reliably protect against aspiration, especially in small-bowel obstruction, and insertion may be limited by the 2-cm mouth opening. Using an SGA as a bridge in this setting exposes the patient to unnecessary aspiration risk.

didactic: RSI is indicated when aspiration risk is high (e.g., small-bowel obstruction, trauma, pregnancy ≥20 weeks, symptomatic GERD/hiatal hernia, obesity, diabetes gastroparesis, or inadequate NPO) and the airway is expected to be straightforward. When hypoxemia risk is prominent but the airway is not predicted to be difficult, a modified RSI with gentle mask ventilation (keep inspiratory pressure ≤$12$–$15$ cm H2O), head-up positioning, and apneic oxygenation can balance oxygenation and aspiration concerns. When high aspiration risk coexists with a predicted difficult airway (difficult laryngoscopy, difficult mask ventilation, limited mouth opening, cervical immobility), an awake intubation that preserves spontaneous ventilation and airway reflexes is safest. Practical steps include aggressive preoxygenation ($3$–$5$ min at FiO2 $=1.0$), ramped positioning, pharmacologic prophylaxis if time allows (nonparticulate antacid, H2 blocker, metoclopramide), and gastric decompression. Use rocuronium $1.2$ mg/kg (or succinylcholine $1$–$1.5$ mg/kg) for RSI when chosen, and limit positive-pressure ventilation pressures to reduce insufflation. Apply cricoid pressure only if it does not impede ventilation or laryngoscopy; release if it worsens the view. A simple rule: full stomach + easy airway → RSI; full stomach + high desaturation risk but easy airway → modified RSI; full stomach + difficult airway → awake intubation.
educationalObjective: Identify clinical indications for rapid sequence induction (RSI) and when modified RSI or awake intubation is safer.

questionText: A 28-year-old man with blunt polytrauma (SBP 92/56 mm Hg, HR 118/min, SpO2 97% on nonrebreather) is rushed to the OR for emergent laparotomy after a positive FAST. He is agitated, last ate 1 hour before the crash, and has midline cervical tenderness; CT of the cervical spine is pending. You remove the anterior portion of the cervical collar and perform rapid-sequence induction with manual in-line stabilization (MILS), apneic oxygenation via nasal cannula at 15 L/min, and a hyperangulated video laryngoscope. An assistant applies cricoid pressure at induction. On laryngoscopy you see only the epiglottis (Cormack–Lehane III) despite optimal blade positioning, and SpO2 drifts to 94%. Suction is ready at the bedside. Which is the best immediate action to facilitate tracheal intubation while minimizing aspiration risk and cervical spine motion?

answers.text: Ask the assistant to release or reduce cricoid pressure, apply optimal external laryngeal manipulation, and pass a bougie under video guidance while maintaining MILS.
answers.explanation: Cricoid pressure often worsens the glottic view and is not proven to prevent aspiration; reducing/releasing it improves exposure. Using a bougie with VL under MILS increases first-pass success without additional cervical motion.

answers.text: Increase cricoid pressure and switch to direct laryngoscopy while maintaining the head in sniffing position.
answers.explanation: More cricoid pressure commonly degrades the view and distorts the airway. Sniffing position and switching to DL increase cervical motion and violate spine precautions.

answers.text: Insert an orogastric tube now to decompress the stomach before reattempting laryngoscopy.
answers.explanation: OG/NG placement before securing the airway can provoke regurgitation and delay intubation. Gastric decompression should occur after the cuffed ETT is in place.

answers.text: Abort and awaken the patient for awake flexible bronchoscopy after cervical spine imaging.
answers.explanation: This unstable trauma patient requires an emergent airway and laparotomy; awakening delays life-saving care. RSI with VL and MILS is appropriate; optimize the current attempt by addressing cricoid pressure.

answers.text: Provide positive-pressure mask ventilation with 25–30 cm H2O inspiratory pressures to restore oxygenation before retrying.
answers.explanation: High mask pressures increase gastric insufflation and aspiration risk. If ventilation is needed, use two-handed mask, PEEP, and keep inspiratory pressure $\le 20$ cm H2O; here, improving the view and intubating promptly is preferable.

didactic: In trauma RSI with suspected cervical spine injury, maintain manual in-line stabilization (MILS), remove the anterior collar for access, and favor video laryngoscopy to minimize cervical motion compared to direct laryngoscopy. Cricoid pressure has not been shown to reliably prevent aspiration and frequently worsens the laryngoscopic view; it should be reduced or released if it impedes ventilation or intubation, and replaced with optimal external laryngeal manipulation. First-pass success is critical—adjuncts such as a bougie markedly improve success under difficult views with VL while preserving neutral neck position. If oxygenation deteriorates, gentle two-handed mask ventilation is acceptable using PEEP and keeping inspiratory pressure $\le 20$ cm H2O (near or below lower esophageal sphincter pressure of $\sim$20–25 cm H2O) to limit gastric insufflation; prioritize suction readiness and apneic oxygenation. Gastric decompression should be performed after securing a cuffed endotracheal tube. Practical sequence: preoxygenate (consider HFNC for apneic oxygenation), MILS with anterior collar off, VL, avoid or loosen cricoid if it degrades the view, apply external laryngeal manipulation, use a bougie early, and have a clear failed-airway plan.
educationalObjective: Integrate cervical spine precautions and aspiration risk mitigation in the trauma patient requiring RSI.

questionText:
A 32-year-old G2P1 at 39 weeks with BMI 36 presents for a category-1 emergency cesarean delivery under general anesthesia due to persistent fetal bradycardia. She ate a full meal 2 hours ago. There is no functioning neuraxial catheter. In the OR, standard monitors are applied; BP is 115/70 mm Hg and HR 105 bpm. When placed flat, she reports lightheadedness and the NIBP transiently drops to 90/55 mm Hg. A wedge is unavailable, but the table can be tilted and a second provider is present. You have ~2 minutes before induction. 

Which combination of positioning and airway management steps is most appropriate now to minimize aspiration risk while maintaining maternal oxygenation and hemodynamics?

answers.text: Ramped 20–30° head-up with manual left uterine displacement; administer 30 mL 0.3 M sodium citrate; 3 minutes of 100% O2 with 5 cm H2O PEEP plus 10–15 L/min nasal cannula for apneic oxygenation; RSI with cricoid pressure and permissive mask ventilation at ≤20 cm H2O until laryngoscopy
answers.explanation: This approach concurrently mitigates aortocaval compression (LUD), improves preoxygenation (head-up, PEEP, apneic oxygenation), and reduces aspiration risk (nonparticulate antacid, cricoid pressure), while allowing gentle ventilation under ≤20 cm H2O to prevent gastric insufflation.

answers.text: Flat supine; RSI with firm cricoid pressure; no mask ventilation before laryngoscopy to minimize aspiration risk
answers.explanation: Supine positioning worsens aortocaval compression and hypotension, and strict no-mask ventilation increases hypoxemia risk in term parturients with reduced FRC and high O2 consumption.

answers.text: 15° Trendelenburg with right-hip bump; RSI with cricoid pressure; avoid PEEP during preoxygenation to prevent gastric insufflation
answers.explanation: Head-down increases regurgitation risk and worsens oxygenation; lack of PEEP reduces preoxygenation efficacy. Aortocaval compression may persist despite a hip bump.

answers.text: Ramped head-up with manual left uterine displacement; omit cricoid pressure to avoid obstructing the view; RSI without cricoid pressure
answers.explanation: While cricoid pressure can be released if it impedes laryngoscopy or ventilation, obstetric RSI still recommends its application at induction to reduce regurgitation risk in a full-stomach patient.

answers.text: Ramped head-up with manual left uterine displacement; preoxygenate, then provide mask ventilation with inspiratory pressures of 30–35 cm H2O; RSI with cricoid pressure
answers.explanation: High mask pressures promote gastric insufflation by exceeding barrier pressure; gentle ventilation with inspiratory pressures ≤20 cm H2O is preferred to balance oxygenation and aspiration risk.

didactic: Term pregnancy increases aspiration risk via decreased lower esophageal sphincter tone and increased intra-gastric pressure, while reduced FRC and higher VO2 shorten safe apnea time. Best practice for obstetric RSI integrates: left uterine displacement (manual or ~15° tilt) to relieve aortocaval compression; ramped 20–30° head-up positioning to increase FRC; and optimized preoxygenation (100% O2, PEEP ~5 cm H2O, and apneic oxygenation via nasal cannula at 10–15 L/min). Give a nonparticulate antacid (30 mL 0.3 M sodium citrate) immediately before induction; H2 blockers and metoclopramide help when time allows. Apply cricoid pressure at loss of consciousness and maintain until ETT placement is confirmed, but release if it impedes ventilation or laryngoscopy. Gentle mask ventilation is appropriate in parturients to prevent hypoxemia, keeping inspiratory pressure ≤20 cm H2O to minimize gastric insufflation; conceptually, barrier pressure is $P_{LES} - P_{gastric}$, and higher mask pressures erode this margin. Practical rule: LUD + head-up + PEEP + apneic oxygenation + cricoid (with readiness to adjust) yields the safest balance of oxygenation and aspiration precautions in the full-stomach obstetric patient.
educationalObjective: Manage the full-stomach obstetric patient with left uterine displacement and aspiration precautions.

questionText:
A 45-year-old woman (BMI 40) with a small-bowel obstruction and repeated emesis is brought for emergent laparotomy. Vitals: BP 152/88, HR 110, RR 22, SpO2 98% on room air. You plan a rapid-sequence induction. The anesthesia machine is checked and functional. You have 3 minutes before the surgeons are ready, and you want to maximize her safe apnea time. Several team members make suggestions as you begin preoxygenation.

Which intervention will most effectively prolong her safe apnea time before RSI?

answers.text: Preoxygenate in a 25° head-up position using a two-hand mask seal with 100% O2 at FGF 10–15 L/min and 5–10 cm H2O CPAP for ~3 minutes (target end-tidal O2 ≥ 90%)
answers.explanation: Head-up positioning increases FRC, and CPAP helps prevent atelectasis, both increasing the alveolar O2 reservoir. A tight mask seal with high FGF speeds denitrogenation and minimizes room-air entrainment, achieving EtO2 ≥ 0.9 and maximally prolonging safe apnea time.

answers.text: Preoxygenate supine for 5 minutes with 100% O2 at FGF 2 L/min using a relaxed one-hand mask seal
answers.explanation: Supine positioning reduces FRC in obese patients, and low FGF plus a loose seal entrain room air, limiting denitrogenation. Time alone cannot overcome ineffective technique; alveolar O2 stores will be suboptimal.

answers.text: Apply cricoid pressure throughout preoxygenation to minimize regurgitation risk
answers.explanation: Early cricoid pressure can worsen mask seal and increase airway resistance, degrading preoxygenation. Cricoid is applied at loss of consciousness for RSI, not during the preoxygenation phase.

answers.text: Use a 50% N2O/50% O2 mixture for preoxygenation to maintain spontaneous respirations
answers.explanation: N2O displaces alveolar O2 and reduces O2 stores, shortening safe apnea time; it also worsens bowel distension in SBO. Preoxygenation should use 100% O2.

answers.text: Have the patient take five vital capacity breaths of 100% O2 and proceed immediately
answers.explanation: The 5-VC breath technique is less effective in obese or tachypneic patients and is inferior to 3 minutes of normal tidal breathing with optimized positioning and seal. It provides insufficient denitrogenation in this context.

didactic: Safe apnea time is primarily determined by the ratio of O2 stores to O2 consumption: $\text{Safe apnea time} \approx \dfrac{\text{O2 stores}}{\dot V_{O2}}$. Alveolar O2 is the largest immediately accessible store and is roughly $\text{FRC} \times F_{AO2}$; thus maneuvers that increase functional residual capacity (FRC) and alveolar $F_{O2}$ prolong safe apnea time. In obese patients, a 20–30° head-up (reverse Trendelenburg) position increases FRC and improves preoxygenation; adding CPAP/PEEP (5–10 cm H2O) further prevents atelectasis and augments FRC. A tight two-hand mask seal with high fresh gas flow (≥10–15 L/min) hastens denitrogenation and minimizes air entrainment; target an end-tidal O2 (EtO2) ≥ 0.9 before induction. Avoid N2O during preoxygenation, as it dilutes alveolar O2 and increases bowel distension. Typical $\dot V_{O2}$ is ~3 mL/kg/min (≈200–250 mL/min in adults), so increasing alveolar O2 content by even 1 L can add several minutes of safe apnea. Optional adjuncts like high-flow nasal cannula for apneic oxygenation can further delay desaturation but do not replace proper preoxygenation with head-up positioning and a tight seal.
educationalObjective: Optimize preoxygenation with head-up positioning and tight-seal techniques to prolong safe apnea time.

questionText: A 62-year-old man with small-bowel obstruction undergoes emergent RSI. During laryngoscopy, copious nonparticulate gastric fluid is seen in the oropharynx. You immediately suction the mouth and quickly intubate. After cuff inflation, endotracheal suctioning yields scant thin fluid without particulate matter. On volume-controlled ventilation ($V_T$ 6 mL/kg IBW, RR 14, $FiO_2$ 1.0, $PEEP$ 0), SpO2 remains 86–88%, peak inspiratory pressure is 35 cm H2O, and coarse crackles are heard bilaterally; hemodynamics are stable. Which is the most appropriate next step in intraoperative management?

answers.text: Increase $PEEP$ to 8–10 cm H2O to recruit alveoli and improve oxygenation
answers.explanation: Aspiration pneumonitis causes alveolar flooding and surfactant dysfunction with increased shunt; early application of $PEEP$ (e.g., 8–10 cm H2O) recruits atelectatic units, reduces $Q_s/Q_t$, and improves oxygenation. Recruitment maneuvers may be considered with hemodynamic monitoring.

answers.text: Start prophylactic broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent aspiration pneumonia
answers.explanation: Chemical (Mendelson) pneumonitis is typically sterile; prophylactic antibiotics do not improve outcomes. Reserve antibiotics for clinical infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis, purulent secretions, new infiltrate after 48–72 h) or known contaminated/colonized aspirate.

answers.text: Perform routine flexible bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage
answers.explanation: Bronchoscopy is indicated when particulate material or lobar obstruction is suspected. Routine lavage after nonparticulate aspiration offers no benefit and may worsen injury by dispersing contents distally.

answers.text: Administer methylprednisolone 125 mg IV to attenuate lung inflammation
answers.explanation: Systemic corticosteroids have not shown benefit in aspiration pneumonitis and may increase infection risk. Supportive ventilatory care is preferred.

answers.text: Reduce ventilatory support by switching to zero $PEEP$ to avoid barotrauma
answers.explanation: ZEEP promotes alveolar collapse and worsens shunt in aspiration injury. Lung-protective ventilation includes low $V_T$ with adequate $PEEP$ to maintain recruitment and oxygenation.

didactic: Immediate management of intraoperative aspiration is airway-first: suction the oropharynx, rapidly secure the trachea, then suction the ETT, deliver 100% $O_2$, and optimize patient positioning (head-up if feasible). Oxygenation typically improves with lung-protective ventilation (low $V_T$ ~6 mL/kg IBW) and application of $PEEP$ (often 5–10 cm H2O) to recruit flooded/atelectatic alveoli and reduce shunt ($Q_s/Q_t$). Flexible bronchoscopy is reserved for suspected particulate aspiration or lobar obstruction; routine lavage after nonparticulate aspiration is not recommended. Prophylactic antibiotics and steroids are not indicated for chemical pneumonitis; start antibiotics only if secondary bacterial infection develops or if contaminated gastric contents are suspected. Obtain a chest radiograph and consider ABG to guide support; aspiration pneumonitis usually evolves within hours and often improves over 24–48 hours with supportive care. Practical rule: suction, secure airway, oxygenate with $PEEP$, consider bronchoscopy for solids, and reserve antibiotics for infection.
educationalObjective: Outline post-aspiration management: suctioning, oxygenation, PEEP, bronchoscopy as needed, and antibiotics only for infection.

questionText: A 56-year-old man (BMI 35) with small-bowel obstruction and repeated vomiting presents for emergent laparotomy. After 3 minutes of preoxygenation at $FiO_2=1.0$, you perform RSI using ketamine and rocuronium $1.2\,\text{mg/kg}$ with cricoid pressure. First-pass video laryngoscopy is unsuccessful (copious secretions, Cormack–Lehane 3b); a bougie attempt fails. Two-person mask ventilation with an oral airway, jaw thrust, and 100% O2 yields poor chest rise and no capnography; $SpO_2$ falls from 98% to 82% over 30 seconds. You have a second-generation SGA and a scalpel–bougie cricothyrotomy kit immediately available. What is the most appropriate next step to re-establish oxygenation?

answers.text: Insert a second-generation SGA immediately and release cricoid pressure if it impedes placement or ventilation
answers.explanation: Oxygenation takes precedence over aspiration risk in a failed RSI. A second-generation SGA provides the fastest path to oxygenation and permits gastric drainage; cricoid pressure should be lightened or released if it obstructs SGA placement or ventilation.

answers.text: Proceed directly to scalpel–bougie cricothyrotomy without attempting an SGA
answers.explanation: Front-of-neck access is indicated once both mask ventilation and SGA oxygenation fail (true CICO). Because an SGA has not yet been attempted and is immediately available, cricothyrotomy is premature.

answers.text: Administer sugammadex 16 mg/kg to reverse rocuronium and allow the patient to awaken
answers.explanation: Reversal does not restore oxygenation and delays definitive action; hypoxemia may worsen during the time to effect. The priority is to re-oxygenate promptly via SGA or, if that fails, front-of-neck access.

answers.text: Attempt another laryngoscopy with the same device using more external laryngeal manipulation
answers.explanation: Repeated laryngoscopy in a rapidly desaturating RSI delays oxygenation and increases airway trauma. Guidelines recommend pivoting to a rescue oxygenation strategy (SGA) rather than persisting with laryngoscopy.

answers.text: Continue two-person mask ventilation while maintaining cricoid pressure to minimize aspiration
answers.explanation: Cricoid pressure can worsen mask ventilation and SGA insertion. Persisting with ineffective mask ventilation risks severe hypoxemia; prioritize establishing oxygenation, releasing cricoid if it impedes it.

didactic: In a failed RSI with rapidly declining $SpO_2$, switch immediately to a predefined rescue pathway that prioritizes oxygenation. The ASA difficult airway algorithm supports early use of a second-generation SGA to restore ventilation even in aspiration-risk patients, as hypoxemia is more immediately life-threatening than aspiration; the SGA’s gastric channel allows decompression to mitigate risk. Cricoid pressure can obstruct mask ventilation, laryngoscopy, and SGA placement—lighten or release it if it impairs oxygenation. If both face mask and SGA oxygenation fail (true CICO), proceed without delay to emergency front-of-neck access (e.g., scalpel–bougie cricothyrotomy). Avoid repeated laryngoscopy attempts that delay oxygenation and increase trauma, and do not rely on pharmacologic reversal to solve a mechanical airway problem. Rapid desaturation is expected in obesity and sepsis due to reduced $FRC$ and increased $V_{O2}$, so decisive action within seconds is critical.
educationalObjective: Recognize failed RSI and initiate a predefined rescue pathway prioritizing oxygenation (SGA or front-of-neck access).

questionText:
A 32-year-old man with a penetrating open-globe injury presents for emergent repair. He ate 2 hours ago and is in severe pain and distress. Planned management is a rapid-sequence induction with rocuronium to avoid raising intraocular pressure. Vitals: BP 92/58 mm Hg, HR 118/min, SpO2 98% on face mask. He has no known medical history and a normal neurologic exam. You aim to minimize increases in intraocular and intracranial pressure while maintaining hemodynamic stability during induction.

Which IV induction agent is the best choice for this RSI?

answers.text: Etomidate 0.3 mg/kg IV
answers.explanation: Best choice. Etomidate provides rapid hypnosis with minimal cardiovascular depression and decreases CBF, CMRO2, ICP, and IOP—ideal for an open globe with borderline hypotension. Single-dose adrenal suppression is clinically negligible in this context.

answers.text: Ketamine 1.5 mg/kg IV
answers.explanation: Common misconception: ketamine is always best for hypotension. While ketamine’s sympathomimetic effects can support BP and contemporary data show it does not increase ICP in ventilated TBI, it can modestly increase IOP—undesirable in open-globe injuries—so it is not the optimal choice here.

answers.text: Propofol 2 mg/kg IV
answers.explanation: Propofol reduces ICP and IOP but frequently causes hypotension due to vasodilation and negative inotropy, which could worsen perfusion in an already borderline BP RSI.

answers.text: Thiopental 4 mg/kg IV
answers.explanation: Thiopental lowers CMRO2, CBF, ICP, and IOP but can produce significant vasodilation and myocardial depression, risking hypotension in this patient.

answers.text: Midazolam 0.2 mg/kg IV
answers.explanation: Misconception: benzodiazepines are safer hemodynamically. At induction doses, midazolam has a slower onset, can still depress BP, and provides less predictable conditions for RSI compared with etomidate.

didactic: Induction agent choice for RSI must balance hemodynamics with neuro-ocular physiology. Etomidate (0.2–0.3 mg/kg) is hemodynamically stable and reduces CBF, CMRO2, ICP, and IOP, making it well-suited for open-globe injuries and suspected elevated ICP. Ketamine (1–2 mg/kg) supports BP via sympathetic stimulation and is generally safe in TBI when ventilated, but it may increase IOP modestly, so it is less desirable for open-globe cases; its direct myocardial depressant effect can also emerge in catecholamine-depleted shock. Propofol and thiopental lower ICP/IOP but often worsen hypotension, compromising cerebral perfusion pressure ($CPP = MAP - ICP$). Midazolam has slower onset and can cause hypotension at induction doses, making it suboptimal for RSI. Practical rule: in borderline hypotension with ocular or intracranial concerns, choose etomidate; in profound shock without ocular constraints, ketamine is reasonable.
educationalObjective: Select induction agents for RSI based on hemodynamics and intracranial/ocular considerations.

questionText: A 54-year-old man (BMI 42) with a small-bowel obstruction and ongoing emesis presents for emergent laparotomy. He is tachypneic but comfortable in a 25° head-up position; SpO2 96% on room air, HR 105, BP 148/86. You preoxygenate with a tight-fitting mask at FiO2 1.0 for 3 minutes and confirm end-tidal O2 of 0.88. You plan a rapid-sequence induction with cricoid pressure and no mask ventilation. To maximize the time to desaturation during laryngoscopy without increasing aspiration risk, which intra-laryngoscopy intervention is best?

answers.text: Apply heated, humidified high-flow nasal cannula at 60 L/min and FiO2 1.0 throughout laryngoscopy
answers.explanation: HFNC at 40–70 L/min provides effective apneic oxygenation by delivering high FiO2, flushing pharyngeal dead space, and generating modest nasopharyngeal pressure, which together extend safe apnea time without positive-pressure ventilation. It does not mitigate CO2 rise but maximizes O2 delivery while preserving RSI principles.

answers.text: Leave a standard nasal cannula at 15 L/min in place during laryngoscopy
answers.explanation: Conventional nasal cannula apneic oxygenation at 10–15 L/min improves time to desaturation, but its effect is smaller than HFNC because it provides less pharyngeal washout and minimal pressure support; thus it is not the most effective option.

answers.text: Perform gentle mask ventilation with PEEP 10 cm H2O while maintaining cricoid pressure
answers.explanation: Although gentle ventilation can improve oxygenation, it introduces positive pressure and gastric insufflation risk in a patient with high aspiration risk, conflicting with classic RSI principles; the question asks for an option that does not increase aspiration risk.

answers.text: Increase the anesthesia machine fresh gas flow to 15 L/min O2 during laryngoscopy
answers.explanation: Raising FGF only increases flow to the breathing circuit; during laryngoscopy the patient is not connected, so this does not deliver oxygen to the airway and will not extend safe apnea time.

answers.text: Intermittently press the oxygen flush valve during laryngoscopy
answers.explanation: The oxygen flush delivers high flow to the circuit, not the patient, and provides no apneic oxygenation when the patient is not connected; it also risks barotrauma if inadvertently delivered while connected.

didactic: Apneic oxygenation exploits ongoing O2 uptake (~250 mL/min) to draw O2 from the pharynx into alveoli even without ventilation; safe apnea time roughly scales with O2 stores (FRC × alveolar O2 fraction) divided by VO2. HFNC (40–70 L/min, FiO2 1.0) is superior to standard nasal cannula because it provides continuous high FiO2, flushes CO2-rich nasopharyngeal gas, and generates low-level CPAP (≈2–5 cm H2O with mouth closed), all of which slow desaturation without applying positive-pressure breaths. Standard nasal cannula at 10–15 L/min also helps and is better than nothing, but the effect size is smaller than HFNC. Apneic oxygenation does not prevent hypercapnia: PaCO2 typically rises ~6 mm Hg in the first minute and ~3–6 mm Hg/min thereafter. Shunt physiology (obesity, pregnancy, atelectasis) reduces the benefit but does not negate it; maximizing preoxygenation (head-up, FiO2 1.0, EtO2 ≥ 0.8) and leaving HFNC in place during laryngoscopy can meaningfully extend safe apnea time. Positive-pressure mask ventilation may improve oxygenation but increases gastric insufflation risk in classic RSI; nasal apneic oxygenation achieves the goal without that trade-off.
educationalObjective: Use apneic oxygenation (e.g., nasal cannula/HFNC) during laryngoscopy to extend safe apnea time.
